Exams were fill in the blank and free response. There’s no test bank so I’d get the list of term down as best as I could. I wish I didn’t read the main textbook as much and read the YJC more. TA’s make the quizzes so it’s really up to who you have. No hw, just a term paper on any topic within the time frame of the class.
Video lectures were easy to understand. Midterm, Paper, and Final. Midterm was fill in the blank and short answer, and the the final was 5, 1 page essays.

There was a five page research paper and a test that consisted of writing 5 one page essays in 3 1/2 hours. There’s no small assignments, so the only things that count towards your grade are the research paper, two tests, and the final. If you’re not a great test-taker, this is a very difficult class.

Definitely don't take for breadth req, although Chrissanthos knows what he's talking about. His lectures are kind of aggravating since he doesn't have slides and just kind of storytells the lectures. The TA you get really determines your grade for this course, and if you get Richard he's super nice. Two midterms (long answer & short answer), one term paper, and one essay final. Lots of memorization, and you'll definitely need the textbooks for this class. Not hard, but not an easy A either.

Chrissanthos is a lovely professor but if the format of the class is not to your particular learning type( he will post a lecture video with an outline) it's probably better to take HIST020 because it is much better formatted to online classes(exams are fill in the blank and short answer and no one likes free response for some reason). If possible take John as your TA, he's not only a great teacher but his questions are very fair and similar to Chrissanthos. You can get away with just reading the book and can get a C but getting an A watching lectures does actually help! do have to read the various primary source parts of the textbook but it is not too hard to do outside of class.

Took this class with Prof Eacott.  Grading is largely determined by how picky your TA is with your essays/midterms.  Please keep in mind there are multiple essays and many assigned readings for this class.  It isn't extremely difficult but not a cakewalk either.
Take Patch if possible. He's a very fun lecturer and his TAs aren't ridiculously difficult graders. If you put in a decent amount of effort, you'll get an A.

Took with Professor Patch; he was a really friendly guy that had a very enjoyable lecture style & demeanor which made the class easy to absorb. It's not a hard class, just a lot of writing. Your assignments & exams will consist solely of essays.
Lots of reading, two assignments (fairly easy), both midterm and final were in class essays. Professor doesn't upload PowerPoints on iLearn so make sure to go to lecture.

For Eacott, make sure you do the readings and attend lecture. There was a lot of readings, but manageable if you do them regularly.The final consists of short responses and two essay questions. The class was interesting, but my TA graded pretty intensely.

Professor Eacott made the lectures really engaging, and does not post the slides online, but going to lectures anyways helps a lot because he gives verbal hints on what's on the midterm/final. There is 3/4 books you need and weekly readings, but it's manageable if you can schedule everything. I procrastinated all readings til finals week, and I passed but with a C, so this class isnt the hardest but if you put in effort it can be fairly easy. Also, your TA plays a large role on your grade because they are the ones that grade your paper. Go to office hours and show you care about passing, and undoubtably it will boost your grade.

Hughes won't put slides online and themes the class in a kind of odd way but isn't bad as a professor. No tests, just in-class essays. Reading-heavy but you don't have to read everything in full. Almost everything is really based on opinion, you can take a little bit of historical fact and as long as it seems thoughtful and you justify it, you can say any bullshit you want.
Jennifer Hughes...2 midterms (2 in class essay each exam)....Take home final. Please don’t take this woman. She’s only here to boost her ego.

professor hughes = a lot of reading! the class is made up of 3 midterms and 1 final, no tests, all essays based on the readings in class. 2 in-class essays, the last 2 are online. she puts up the lecture slides online, but she doesn't put up all of the slides (ie. you have to go to class to see some key facts/slides), she also gives you potential essay questions in-class and she'll choose one for your midterm. not the hardest class to take, but it will require a lot more effort

Took it with Prof Hughes, she treats the class like a W class; the midterms and final are all essays. There are 3 midterms on books and articles that you have to read; she doesn’t talk about them in class or give you enough supporting evidence during lecture. She didn’t really know what she was teaching. Half the class was either asleep or just didn’t come to lecture. Discussion’s really important, talk to your TA’s and go to office hours because they’re the one’s grading the essays. Class is easy but she’s difficult.

had Hughes for lecture, gives 3 midterms and 1 final, all essays. each midterm is based on a book she has you read and it's very boring if you don't like history. If you get a ta who is an easy grader you'll be fine with a decent amount of effort. try not to fall behind on readings as the midterms and final are based on what you read.

Took with Patch. Class consists of one essay (based on readings), a midterm (IDs and an essay), a final (IDs and 2 essays, one based on the entire course and another based on 2nd half of course). There's a geography quiz in discussion towards the beginning of quarter. Lecture was pretty fun, but the notes he posts on iLearn are pretty vague so you have to pay attention in class. He doesn't have slides, just kinda rambles on about history. Discussion sections and mandatory and you need to do the readings to participate. THERE IS SO MUCH READING IN THIS CLASS. There's 3 assigned books, weekly assigned readings on iLearn, and weekly assigned readings from the textbook. You will be reading every single week. If you get behind it's hard to catch back up.

Robert Patch explains everything you need in lecture, so go to his lectures and record them. His outlines are good, but all the details are in the lectures. Lots of readings and essay due at the end of the quarter. Prepare for essays for the midterm and final as well

Attending lecture is only necessary for the first half up til the midterm for Patch. Afterwards I just used my notes from discussion. My TA (Emily) was great though idk how useful the other TAs are. It's useful to make a document of all the readings and a summary of them. In general though look for patterns in the history, he'll point some out too.

It's not a hard class but god, it is a lot of reading. I took it with Professor Robert Patch and I did not learn anything. His class is really disorganized, so try to get a good TA. The reading was basically 100+ pages a week. This class is not for lazy people. But I got a B in the class without managing to do any of the readings. The tests are not multiple choice so they are purely essay based. It is do-able, but stressful. Honestly I would take HIST010 if I were you because this class requires you to spend a lot of $$$ on books

[COVID-19 ERA: SPRING 2020] Took this class with Eacott. I was honestly dreading this class because this was the only lower-div class I had to take with my other upper-div classes, but Eacott made this class really interesting. He was also VERY understanding because of COVID-19 and the entire quarter being online. No exams; just two papers, lots of readings (which I will admit I forgot to do a lot of lol) and a big final project (in groups). Papers can be hard depending on how picky your TA is. If your TA is Clayton, then you're good to go, he's a super chill TA. The second paper was made optional and we got an extension on the final project due to #BLM. Highly recommend Eacott. Class isn't difficult, but definitely don't forget about this class either. Also, Eacott is very handsome :)
Take with prof downs if you can! During Winter 2021, just weekly readings and listening ti podcasts. No midterms or finals, just a book review final which was 6-8 pages

description: WORLD HISTORY: THE LONG TWENTIETH CENTURY

comments.comment: Lots of reading and essays. Midterm/finals were short answer/essay questions.
I barely went to lecture (about half before midterm, twice after) and I got out with an A-.
Do the readings, David Biggs’ lectures are a mess but go anyway, papers were graded really lax but actually put some effort in and you’ll do great

dont take this class this professor assigns 30 pages per lecture reading.. insane and has a super strict TA that grades like crazy i did all of the readings and he gave me a F. im super pissed rn and waiting for my response why i got this grade.

Be careful with the TA you pick. I had Prof. Hawkins and TA David Shanta and he was much more tedious when it came to grading. Go to office hours with your TA to figure out what they want since they grade everything (1 midterm 1 final 1 paper) very interesting material and loved the assigned readings! Best history class to choose in my opinion. Hawkins had a young spirit and kept us interested especially with his jokes

Professor Juliette Levy's class is SO easy. There's NO EXAMS, only small writing assignments. The lectures are asynchronous and are in the forms of short podcasts (that she provides transcripts for). I hate history but this class is actually really fun I'd definitely recommend. Also a lot of extra credit.

Took it with Hawkins, he's a really nice professor! Your grade is composed of 2 midterms, a final, and discussion section. Each midterm is 2 long essay questions, and the final is based off the books you read in class, not lecture material. Took it online: asynchronous lecture, synchronous discussion. I feel like your grade depends on your TA since they do the grading and some might be more strict with their grading than others.

(Taken online during Winter 2021) This is probably the easiest history course you can take since there are no exams. There are only quizzes that are extra credit, which can boost your grade up to 10%. There's also short weekly podcasts that you have to write comments for, but are graded on completion. Most of your grade depends on the decade assignments, which are short 400+ word essays. The prompts were sometimes confusing, but it didn't take up that much of my time to write. There were 4 of these assignments and it is graded by your TA, so you grade kinda depends on how nice they are and if you basically follow the rubric, it shouldn't be too hard to do well on these essays. Apparently, there was supposed to be one decade assignment per week (pre-COVID), but she changed to biweekly assignments to make it easier for students in the pandemic. She also made the final optional for us. It was a relatively easy A class for most people as long as you complete all the assignments, come to discussion, and do all the extra credit quizzes.

description: RACE & ETH IN THE ANC MED WLD

comments.comment: Super easy class for history majors, just keep up with the work, and it is an easy A. Most local libraries have the World War Z book online so just make an account to access it.
It's a mandatory workshop for History majors. Take Professor Levy online. Easy assignments even if they're tedious. Easy A.

Took the class Fall 2020. Online. Professor Lentacker was very reasonable. Instead of meeting our scheduled times, he separated the class into 4 discussion sections where we meet only once a week. No exams but there was a final paper and other writing assignments throughout the quarter.
Pretty easy, almost always gives out A+ for minimal effort, 3 multiple choice tests are open everything
Ramps up in difficulty towards the end, papers are a joke but I have no idea how they grade the papers (fall 2020) so just do the 1 reading a week
Very easy upper division breadth course. Took in fall 2020 with Tofigh. 3 multiple choice tests, 2 essays plus a final essay
Class grade was based on three multiple choice tests and two essays. As long as you read the required readings and went to lecture it was pretty easy to get an A.

Took with Tofigh. People complaining are probably because they don't follow his essay instructions. If you want to ace his essays, literally open a google doc and just spill all your knowledge on the subject that comes DIRECTLY from the reading or the powerpoints. Dont use any fancy stuff or fluff or anything that doesn't come from the reading or powerpoint. Easy A. Study powerpoints for tests, test material comes straight from powerpoint/lecture material
Got an A- with zero effort, just do well on the multiple choice exams to get an A. The midterm and final are essay-based that focus on mentioning all the key points.

description: ANCIENT GREECE: THE HELLENISTIC AGE FROM ALEXANDER TO CLEOPATRA, 336-31 B.C.

comments.comment: Brian Lloyd taught the class and the entire grade was 50% midterm and 50% final, each test is 10% multiple choice on the reading, 10% multiple choice on lecture, and 80% essay that is turned in on test day 5 pages. His grading is very difficult and no rubric is ever given. Extremely monotone and enters tangents frequently. Asked my friends after the class was over what they got and highest grade was a B. Would not take the professor again.

Took this class with Professor Gudis and it was a breeze. She has readings every week that are time consuming, but super interesting. She is incredibly flexible and understanding, so if you have trouble just reach out. We had weekly quizzes, a midterm essay and a final essay. They all had due dates, but you would not be penalized for being late. That being said, you really have to discipline yourself because otherwise it all piles up at the end and is overwhelming. Overall though, easy class and really enjoyable if you stay engaged. Gudis also helped me to get my internship, so she's a really cool person to make a connection with.

description: THE SUPREME COURT AND THE CONSTITUTION
AMERICAN MUSICAL SUBCULTURES: A GENEALOGY OF ROCK

comments.comment: took it with miura. great professor, and will do his best to explain something if you ask, but can come off as kind of intimidating lmao. tons of quizzes and homework assignments that really do add up, and are pretty simple, so don't slack off. 3 exams, and one oral exam at the end of the quarter. passed with an 89%. don't take this class if you hate cold calling tho

the prof, jorge montesinos, was very into the material and gives u  chances to redeem ur grade via extra credit assignments after the midterm. 2 exams which were just a takehome midterm and takehome final which were graded pretty easy. he doesnt post lecture notes so going to lecture is a must and ur grade is basically just the exams but he curves slightly dependuing on class avg

description: INTRODUCTION TO THE STUDY OF LAW AND SOCIETY

comments.comment: Quizzes are super easy, but weren’t worth a lot. Quiz questions were given ahead of time. Homework is a BIG part of your grade & the TAs grade homework in a very strict manner. Do not use internet sources or peers for your homework or else you’ll be excused if cheating & reported to student conduct (our professor would threaten us every week about this lmao). Exams are fairly easy, study the study guide slides & you’ll do fine. Our prof said she’d curve the grades at the end. But avoid Prof Chidambaram PLZ lol
Professor is a horrible teacher. Relatively unhelpful TA. If you somehow still want to take this class, do NOT take it with Vrinda Chidarbarm.

This class is basically the same as LING021 except 21 is much more focused on grammar; 20 is more broad and easier, in my opinion. If you're someone who's naturally good at English/foreign languages then this is an easy A as long as you take notes during lectures (even if you're a STEM person this class still isn't very hard). I had Dr. Heidi Waltz, she's really sweet and tries her best to keep everyone engaged.
Buy the book, get Dr. Waltz. Class is pretty simple, every lesson is taken straight from the book!

I had Heidi Waltz as a professor, would recommend. Just attend lecture, and take notes. She only tests on material that you go over in class. She gives helpful study guides with topics that tests will go over. Just look over the study guide with your notes and you should be good. The final exam was not cumulative and only tested on material learned after the midterm. She gives full credit on homework as long as you attempt it.

This class is unnecessarily difficult. The material isn’t even that hard to comprehend but Vrinda Chidambaram is a bad teacher and makes it too complicated. On top of that, homework is graded based on accuracy out of 5 points and it’s worth 40% of your grade. You lose points very easily on homework; the answer may be correct but if it’s not written correctly you will lose points. It’s obvious Chidambaram does not care about her students and their success. In lecture, listen attentively but DO NOT ask a question that’s been asked before. She will yell at you. This class desperately needs discussion sections. Everyone I know is failing.

This class was so hard with Professor Chidambaram!! do not take it when you are have a lot on your plate. She made this class wayyyyy too hard than it seems. Thank God I took this class during remote learning. If I took the class in person, I probably would have done credit/no credit or failed.

description: INTRODUCTION TO COLLEGE MATHEMATICS FOR THE SCIENCES

comments.comment: The work itself is easy, but if you have Lizheng Tao consider yourself done for. Curve is strong though.

Took over summer so it was more fast paced, but even then the class was not bad at all. No curve, but there is a redo your lowest page on the midterm from 6A. Covers modules 5-8 and they are all easy but the only one I found challenging was 8 because its trig functions and they don't click in my head lol. Got C's on all exams/finals, but completed all homework/ discussion worksheets and ended with a 85% so do the homework and worksheets.
Midterms and finals are just like the sample ones, memorize them and you'll do fine
Sample midterms and finals are very similar to the actual exams.

Had Professor Karl Smidtch. He is a horrible lecture (over complicates things) but his midterms and final are wayyyy easier than the ones given by other teachers. I would take his class because 7A is just derivatives and applications of derivatives so it isn't hard and his midterms/final are pretty easy. If you took calc before you're straight chillin in his class, but I didn't take calc in hs and still found 7A pretty chill. Study the mictotutorials though, he puts one of them on his final.

costello is a really good teacher, he explains his work it detail so you can understand how to solve similar problems. 2 midterms and a final, hw due every week online but you have unlimited tries per problem so its an easy 100%

Took with Costello, great professor. Has 2 midterms 1 Final that are relatively easy imo, as long as you attend lecture you’ll get a good grade because his lectures are clear and easy to understand. Final is worth 40% of grade and is cumulative, also has micro tutorials that aren’t due till finals week so lots of time to get them done. Online hw every week with unlimited tries so no excuse not to do, plus they’re relatively short. Discussion and lecture attendance not necessary but highly recommend you attend lectures, discussions were a waste of time imo.

I had henry tucker. he improved his organization skills every class and layed out the possible math questions for each concept on the following test. he gave us 4 sampe mid terms each midterm and gave us 4 sample finals which were, if not, identical to the real midterm and finals.

I had Dr. Constantini during Fall 2020 and she's the sweetest person ever. Her lectures and TA discussions are not mandatory but she offers supplemental notes and recorded lectures. Homework consists of Microtutorials, worksheets,  and MyMathLab. She really does want you to do well and is always willing to help her students out. Her practice exams are really similar to her actual exams and all of them are unproctored and open notes. You don't even have to be in Zoom, she just emails you your version of the test and you have to turn it into GradeScope by a specific time. Material is mostly the first semester of AP Calc.

i had robbie lopez as prof even tho he's apparently a grad student? super easy going jacked as fuck literal chad super good at explaining concepts. just do the homework and don't forget the micro-tutorials and u basically get an A

This class was really, really easy. I had Christina Va..(something complicated; greek) and it was fun. I did not pay much attention in class, but I was there. It was easier than AP calc. I used like 10% of my brain in class and got an A, but I know some people who had a hard time. I say just study, do the homework, and be attentive and it will all be okay.
Very easy with Dr. Christina. Show up to office hours and you’ll definitely get an A
Had Stefano Vidussi. Does not teach very well, rarely shows examples in class, so you're better off studying on your own. Midterm is easy, but final is much harder
Avoid Gindi at all costs. He will show up to class at least 10-15 minutes late every lecture, give out hard exams, and will be condescending to those who asks questions.
HELL

If you took calc AB in high school, this is basically the 2nd half of that class since it is all about integrals. Quizzes are very easy and midterm/final aren't as easy, but are not hard. I had Scott Atkinson who was a good professor and had a good TA as well. Some newer concepts not learned in calc AB are taught in the second half of the course. Make sure to understand all the concepts as some people struggle(maybe due to bad math background or using symbolab to do all the homework)

Took it w Atkinson. He's not a bad prof, but I feel likes he's a little too roundabout and has a tendency to overcomplicate concepts. If you took Calc AB in hs, this is mainly a review w a few new tricks on familiar concepts. Homework is weekly and kind of a bother bc the system can be picky about "correct" answers. For instance, it often does not recognize answers that are equivalent to its own so you kind of have to solve problems very formally. Weekly quizzes in discussion, but the TAs do a great job of walking you through the concept and then quizzing you at the end of discussion. Tests aren't too bad
Took it with Prof. Atkinson. Amazing guy but at times can be boring and repetitive. Make sure you pay attention and take notes :)

I had professor Zhanar Berikkyzy and hands down the best math professor at UCR. She is hella patient, and does not go fast at all. She truly wants nothing but the best for her students and even if you show the slightest interest by asking questions or office hours, she is extremely helpful and considerate. I struggled through 7B material, but she was extremely helpful in office hours and after class. I flew through 7A, but 7B was a struggle for me because I hate integrals but overall 7B isn't hard. Her midterms are similar to the ones in her class examples and quizzes that were given in discussion.

Had Burdick. HONESTLY GOAT you have 1-2 homework assignments due every Friday with unlimited attempts. Asynchronous class but he held optional class at normal times and had office hours to go over any homework questions you have. Recorded lessons for the week posted Sundays and he records all his office hours and lectures. One worksheet a week for discussion (attendance optional) that you would turn in for grades. Provided four samples for every midterm (1&2) and the final exam. Very helpful.

(Fall 2020 Via Zoom) I gave this class a 4/10 in difficultly because the concepts are not hard to grasp if you do the assigned homework and attend discussions as they do a good job of working step-by-step through difficult problems. I had Dr. Chen, and he was great. He gave us enough time to do homework problems and they were not long. The homework problems are more complex than those on the exams which I think is good because you will be prepared for the exams. The averages were about 80-85%. The midterms (2) and final are all free-response and must be worked out and turned in via Gradescope. As far as proctoring, he required us to log into zoom and have our cameras on and no calculators allowed. He also did offer one extra credit quiz. DOWNSIDE: He only uploads his notes that he takes during the live lecture but does not record the actual lecturing. However, he does upload example videos of him going through various problems for the modules.

I took this with Prof. Chen in Fall 2020, and I thought he was a really nice prof that wants his students to succeed. If you need anything, just contact him and he'd be happy to help you out however you need. Lectures were pretty boring (although I find all math lectures boring) but it was easy to follow. I took Calc BC in high school, so having had a lot of practice with integrals, this class was a breeze for me. My friend, who took Calc AB in high school, was less familiar with some of the material but they're still getting through the class with only mild difficulty; so make sure you pay attention in lecture!!!

Specifically with Gerhard Gierz, the exams are open EVERYTHING even internet and the questions are literally taken from his homework! I got an A+ and showed up to like 70% of the classes but some of my friends who never showed up also got As

Never took calculus before and it kicked my ass. Got a C. Gerard Gierz, I believe was his name, let students use their electronic devices for the exam. I didn't utilize it properly because I did not know what the hell I was doing

Probably my easiest class this quarter even though I didn't take calculus in high school. I had Vasilakopoulou and she taught pretty well, even if it was a bit fast. Pay attention and ask questions, it will make sense.

Kadriye Nur Saglam is not a good professor; cannot explain things clearly. You're better off reading the textbook and never going to lecture. I heard she is better at teaching during office hours than lecture, though.

Attend lecture and sections. Both help out with getting material review. Class is exam and quiz heavy. If you need help there is many guides online and tools. There is review packets online that are extremely useful.
I really liked having professor benson. He assigned hardly any homework, and his exams seemed very fair (if not a little easy). He will stare into your soul

Brian Benson - Very enthusiastic and energetic teacher. Teaches us why things works and makes us show work and provide reasoning instead of plugging in numbers. He made the final exam and midterm much easier than the practice one posted by the department. If you already took AB, this class will be easy. Class average on midterms were around an 88% and i got a 102% on them.
If you have prior calculus experience, it’s relatively easy and a good review.

Took it with Dr. Zilong Song (this was his first year teaching I think). He was pretty good but he had an accent that some may find hard to understand. Do at least the first and last problems of webwork and MAKE SURE to be up to date on microtutorials because those come in clutch at the end for bonus points. Midterms and finals are pretty easy, almost exactly like class examples and webwork but are not curved. go to discussion if you don't get something. study for discussion quizzes, they add up over time.
Took it with Professor Song, he writes out all of the notes for you and emails them. Just do the hw and review the notes and you should be fine.

I took this class with Professor Qi Zhang. He has an accent, but it wasn't too hard to understand him. He's also nice and cares about his students. It was my first time taking calc and I ended up with an A. Qi's lectures can be all over the place sometimes, but he still gets his point across. His office hours help if you don't understand something. For the homework, if you run out of tries, you can email him for more. Quizzes are given out during discussion; the problems depend on who your TA is. The midterm wasn't too bad, but you need to put in the time and effort to study. Because of the coronavirus, the final was online and open notes, but it would have been closed notes and in-person.
Dr. Wang is extremely tough to follow. Don’t even bother going to lecture.

I had Professor Xin Yang Fall 2020, he's super nice and always gives students access to lectures and lecture notes for the entire quarter which I found really helpful for the midterms. Considering the rigor of this course I honestly don't think it gets better than this cuz he explains everythinggg in depth and does it pretty well. He's also super reasonable and understanding. So try to get him if you take this course :) In terms of content, if you're a freshman and you didn't take any AP Calc courses but placed into this, its definitely gonna be overwhelming. There's always gonna be kids who know more than you since they had more experience with it. You can do well even if you procrastinate but beware that it's a LOT of cramming. Make sure you study for the quizzes because it's easy to forget considering how much we have to remember. Be attentive during lecture, you miss one thing and can get lost and then needa rewatch it. Also, he monitors the chat so you don't have to speak to participate. Overall, a rigorous course but he's a really good professor so you'll be in good hands :)

I had prof Xin Yang and we was a super sweet prof. He didn't take attendance, but lectures were super helpful. Tests and quizzes were all open note, but had some tricky questions that required you to apply concepts you had learned from the notes. It helps to have friends in the class who can help you if you get stuck on a homework problem or if you go to office hours. Also ask a lot of questions because it really helps.
Prof Gan - the best! No midterms, no finals. Just do the hw and quizzes and you're all set. Definitely take Wee Lian Gan. Just take him. !
Lopez-Garcia is a great professor
similar to high school AP calculus

Fernando Lopez-Garcia was a good professor and good looking too. I understood everything until we got to divergence and convergence. Homework was graded fairly, but the quizzes were not given any partial credits.

Avoid Chenxu He as your professor. First 3/4 of class were easy, but towards the end it became moderately difficult. He also doesn't let you use notes or cheatsheets in exams, which is a let down considering this class was mostly utilizing and memorizing identities.

Prof. Theerakarn was definitely new to teaching. He did not explain well to a point where there everyone was confused and one girl would constantly ask him "I did not understand any of that, can you explain the whole thing over again?" Midterm was just like the practice midterm. The final had a few curveballs. Midterm and final were pretty easy if you understood the material and the TAs graded really leniently.

If you've taken AP Calculus AB in high school, you know a good portion of the material already. Know how to do the practice midterms and finals, as they are a good representation of the actual exams you will take. I had Jose Gonzalez, and he is probably one of the best professors I've had so far.

Like most other math classes at this level, if you're good at running through problems without making careless errors and can understand the concepts and how they apply to the actual formulas, you should do alright. First half of the class is just the FTC, U-Subs, and integration by parts, second half is application problems and stuff like trig sub. Still hard enough, but not GPA-ruining if you're willing to put in the work.
Had Po-ning Chen, Hw was super easy, one midterm/final that are extremely similar to the practice tests that he provides

Hard tests, professors are hit or miss on quality depending on who you get. Tests are different between sections and difficulty also varies by professor. Every question missed on the final is half a grade down so it is hard to keep an A

Had Po-Ning Chen. He was a pretty good lecturer, posted his slides and lecture notes online after class. Unlimited tries on homework questions. I took AP Calculus AB in high school, and most of the stuff I learned in 9B, I had already learned in high school. Midterm was extremely, extremely easy. Final was a bit more difficult than midterm in my opinion.

Fall 2019. Took with Liwei Chen. If you took AP Calculus in High School, class is very easy because it's material from AP Calc. Online HW was easy if you understood the material, but annoying. Quizzes during discussions which were mildly difficult. 1 Midterm and 1 Final.

Took it with John Baez. Very passionate teacher and explains the concepts in depth. Put in the effort and go to office hours for help. Homework is online and tests are almost identical to practice exams. Ended with an A+

Had prof qi zhang spring 2020, aka corona season lol. He went really fast, spent too much time on easy concepts and too little time on the harder ones. this class is very straightforward. webwork due every week, microtutorials, and a final for me. its really not bad at all

Had Po-Ning Chen. The class was really easy if you've taken AP Calc in highschool. The only thing I didn't like was how the finals felt compared to everything else in the class. Much harder than the rest of the stuff but might've just not studied hard enough. Would recommend overall.
I had Sarah Yeakel. You have to make sure you attend to class, watch YuJa videos, do hw, and do the weekly worksheets to stay on top of the class. There’s also weekly quizzes and microtutorials.

I had Dr. Wee Liang Gan, He is very kind and will answer emails right away. Sometimes he does not explain context? To avoid confusion, pre-view the textbook before the class. it takes about 15 minutes to do so, and makes the class easier to understand. He gave no midterm or final, but he gave 10, 10 minute quizzes for each chapter. The quizzes are a bit rushed, but it is not that hard. Just review the homework questions by finishing them in a spread out manner, then reviewing them the day before the test. It is not a hard class to get an A in. If you are ever confused, send an email. Be careful on quizzes and take organized notes, because quizzes are open book/note. The class structure is organized and easy to understand.
Basically unrelated to 9A or 9B so beware
Not bad if you can study for it, sick curves
It's known to be a tricky course but honestly if you study the theorems enough to where you know them like the back of your hand you'll be fine.

This class mainly covers power series and is an easy A for most people, especially if you took AP Calculus BC in high school. Two quizzes, one midterm and a final. Do your homework and you will be fine. Ended with an A- because I forgot one formula which basically costed my A. The midterm and final were similar to the practice ones given by the professor so that should be your main mode of studying.
Nothing like 9A or 9B. New concepts make it hard to apply anything you previously learned here. As long as you pay attention and attend lectures and practice, you'll be good.

Ziv Ran is probably the worst professor in the 9 series as he tends to overcomplicate simple concepts in lecture while giving difficult problems in exams. Quizzes and homework are easy and make up a decent chunk of your grade.
Had Dong, basically gives you midterm and final the lecture before
Professor Gindi is horrible at teaching. The quarter ended and we were missing 3 weeks worth of material.

Fall 2018 Quarter - Professor Gindi
Our midterm average was a 70.8 IIRC - he said since our midterm average was above a 70, he wouldn't curve it... The final screwed me over. Cannot miss a single lecture as some of the stuff he goes over in class is on the midterm/final and isn't found in the textbook... overall this class was extremely difficult in my opinion. There is a pretty large curve though (90 A, 85 A-, 80 B+ etc.)
Costello is great, but can spend a lot of time on the theory and proofs behind certain concepts.

Material isn't too hard, but the class difficulty is dependent upon the professor you have. Midterm and final was similar to the practice problems given to us. If you have Kadriye Nur Saglam, I'd try to steer clear. She fell behind schedule frequently and had to rush through the material to finish the course before the final exam.

I had Dr. Diaz. He's fairly good at teaching and he's more than willing to help you with any questions that you may have or if you're stuck on a homework problem. Math009C is strange at first because it's NOTHING like Math009B or 9A and it's very stressful because you're going to be like "what have I gotten myself into." My advice is just realize that this class is 75% memorization and 25% math manipulation and start memorizing as soon as you can... I eventually got used to it in the end but even toward the midterm I was stressed out about this class.

Took it with John Baez. He is a very theoretical professor and doesn’t teach the best. I did very well in 9A and 9B but I had to fight for a B in this class. Always clicker questions every lecture but discussion quizzes were always on the clicker which i thought was pretty cool.
Midterm mostly had questions from in class examples or from the written homework.

Difficult class. Taylor polynomials and series are absolutely brutal and will destroy you if you do not understand them. Zhenghe Zhang is a great professor and if you go to office hours he will definitely help you. The course material is difficult but you can get an A if you put in a lot of effort. Make sure to get 100% on quizzes as it's based off the hw. The midterm is 30% and the final is 50%, so you really have to study hard and make sure you do a lot of practice problems and not make any silly mistakes.

Took it with Mahesh. He has easy midterms and finals. the curve is preset (A+ 95-100 A 90-95 A- 85-90). his lectures are extremely boring and useless so do problems out of the book as much as you can. quizzes cover the really easy problems of each concept. they are given out during discussion so go to discussion!!

avoid song zilong, accent is understandable but i spend a heavy amount of time trying to understand wtf hes saying and dont really have the brain power at 8am to actually comprehend it. he has a tablet for notetaking that he projects and will switch to a new page with complete disregard for if anyone is still unfinished copying down on what he wrote, which is often.
webwork is also due at 10pm and not 11:59pm which is a huge pain in the ass

Took it with Zilong Song, would not recommend because he has a very static voice and just writes on his device and goes over a bunch of examples without really explaining the concept well. The first half of the class isn’t too bad you just need to memorize the different types of convergence tests but the second half really picks up. I didn’t take Calc BC in hs so I found this class kinda hard but if you just watch YouTube videos on the concepts covered (I recommend organic chemistry tutor) you should be fine.
Had a 100% until the final, which fucked me. Ended up with a B+
Math is hard in general for me, but in general, practice makes perfect, so if you put in the time and effort, you should be fine.

If you're good with first-year calculus, this class is a breeze. It helps even more if you've already taken MATH 031 (though some say to take 10A first). Took it with Neal. He was a pretty good professor, but he confused himself at some points in the lecture.

Take Bingyuan Liu, since he takes his time teaching the material and is an easy teacher. Do good on the midterm, complete all the homework, and do good on the quizzes. The final will reflect the structure of the homework, so its an easy A.

Took it with Professor Po-Ning Chen. Provides detailed lecture notes that are in a very easy to read format and follow extremely well in lecture. Midterm and final exam are very close to the study guides. Homework and quizzes are not too difficult. He prepares you well and responds quickly to any questions.
This is honestly easier than 9B. It's basically 9A but you have an extra variable. Just do the homework and practice problems and you'll be set.

Took it with Neal Livesay. Looking back it wasn't so bad, but I made it difficult for myself because I didn't do enough practice problems for the midterm and I got a 50%. That being said do some practice problems every week and you should do fine. Lectures were good and contained all the material for the midterms and finals, much better than the book that has a lot of jargon that makes the material difficult. Homework was overall ok, there was only one long homework assignment(2-4 hours). The midterms and finals and class overall aren't curved, but he does boost everyones midterm and finals by the difference of the highest score and the max score. For example, if the midterm is out of 30 points and the highest score is 28, he gives everyone 2 extra points on their midterm grade. He also tells you whats going to be on the midterm and final the day before.

Took it with Gan Wee, it was suuuuper easy. He allowed a full page front and back of notes during the midterm and final. Had 5 point quizzes that you got full credit for as long as you get 3 or more problems correct. Homework has unlimited chances on webassign (except multiple choice but those didn't show up often). Practice exams are pretty similar to actual exams except the final had a surprise from the first half of the class that seemed to trip a lot of people up since it wasn't on the practice, but it is cumulative so we should've been prepared.
LOOK for professor Vasilakopoulou, Christina! She's a really good professor and the class isn't easy but she teaches well so its sort of easy.

I found it SO much easier than 9C. Prof Lapan was a great prof and I kind of wish I have her again since she explained things relatively well and she's pretty friendly and willing to explain things again to you if needed.
The class is pretty straight forward. Easier than 9C in my opinion. Just study class notes. Take with Vasilopoukou she is a fantastic professor. DO HER WORKSHEETS

I took the class with Costantini, she was honestly so nice and helpful. None of the questions on the midterm and final were curve balls. She gives practice problems for both exams. Overall, pretty easy class.
Took the class with Tucker. He prepares you for exactly what will be on the exams and his practice midterm and finals are very similar to the actual exams.
MATH010A is a very difficult class. I would say it's harder than MATH009C, which I already struggled in. Avoid Kelliher at all costs, and stay on top of the material!
Not as much calc as ppl think

There is a notable amount of material, but most concepts are fairly straightforward. If your professor has open-book exams, it should be an easy A. I had Frederick Wilhelm (Fall 2020). He was a really great teacher, and you could tell he likes what he does. However, the exams were closed-book. Basically, if you understand basic linear algebra and Math 009A, this class is very manageable.

Took it online Fall 2020 pandemic with Prof Fred Wilhelm. He's knows the material well and is often happy to help. Overall the class wasn't too bad. There were weekly quizzes and homework, 1 midterm and 1 final. He uses 3 grading scales so there are many ways to get an A even if you mess up somewhere.

Took it with Vidussi; had some technical difficulties, but did not intrude on learning environment. He records all the lectures so class attendance isn't necessarily mandatory. Homework is 1 online worksheet (usually between 7-25 questions) per lesson. Not a very demanding class. If you regularly attend lectures and discussions, and do your homework, you will be fine. The midterm/final is exactly like the practice ones he gives, so be sure to do them.

I took Professor Vidussi, and all I can say is that he is a nice, wholesome person however he can’t really teach. He spends all lecture on theorems and 1-3 examples which makes it extremely difficult to do the homework as the material is not reflecting off theorems. Most people stop attending lecture and independently studied the textbook. Exams were not bad since he provided a sample midterm(which was super helpful) but don’t expect it to be identical to the exam. Lastly, his exams are timed to be 30minutes so you must rush through each problem.

Unlike 9A, most of this class isn't actually about calculus but rather general problems involving 3D space/matrices. If you autopiloted through 9A this class may be hard for you but if you can think though a problem conceptually you should do fine.
Didn't really go to class, didn't really understand the material but ended up with an A- somehow

Take the class with Yilan Tan if possible; he is super enthusiastic, friendly and helpful. Not to mention he curves the class immensely(I somehow got an A despite not "feeling" like I put enough effort to warrant it, if that makes sense).

Took the class with Jacob Greenstein. 70% weekly quizzes and 30% final. All the quizzes had 50% EC, so some students didn't even have to take the final to get an A. I didn't go to class. Study off of the homework solutions before the quiz and it's an easy A+

Took it with Neal Livesay. 40% Final, 60% quizzes. He basically told you what would be on the quiz that week and the final consisted of questions very similar to the quiz questions. I honestly didn't understand what I was doing but I got an A by listening to his hints in lecture.
Had Dr. Livesay. Study the proofs and you'll be fine.

CS011 with Livesay was hard in the beginning until you realize all the quiz questions are either verbatim from examples in lecture or from his suggested problems list that he gives answers to more than 3/4 of. The midterm and final are so similar to previous quarters so if you have a friend that was in it before you, try getting it from them. He also drops your lowest quiz as well. Overall just study the topics and examples for that weeks quiz and you’re bound to get 100% on all of them.

Had Greenstein. Not a very good lecturer, but offers more than enough extra credit to make the class a breeze. Quizzes during discussions; it’s more than enough just to glance at the hw before. Didn’t have to take the final if you had a grade you wanted by the time of the final.

If you have Jacob Greenstein as your professor, it's the biggest dub in the world. No midterm, just 60% quizzes and 40% final. He gives 30% extra credit for watching his video tutorials online, and a max of 20% extra credit on quizzes, so you might not even have to take the final to get an A in the class. His lectures aren't really helpful, study off of the slides and the video tutorials for the quizzes. Quizzes are like the homework problems, just ask the TAs to go over some of the HW questions before the quiz is handed to you. If you have anyone other than Greenstein, this class is very difficult. Many of my friends who had other professors, and it was extremely hard for them. Some barely passed with a C-, but they will be prepared for CS111, which builds upon this course.
Avoid professor Bin Sun if it’s possible, his (I think) Korean accent is such a barrier that his lectures are slow as heck. We had three subsitutes and they were all far better

I had Neal Livesay. He's a nice guy but often times has trouble explaining abstract concepts like why a certain rule makes sense which is really what a lot of students struggle with since this class is not that intuitive. Honestly I felt like I didn’t really know what I was doing for most of this quarter but I just looked at his solutions for the practice problems, tried to find some sort of pattern, and did the same thing. Try to study for this class and attend lecture and make sure you have all the notes written down so you can clarify it on discussion. Still
Probably won’t make sense lol. Do well on quizzes and study for the final cuz it’s a huge chunk of the grade (50%)

Had this during coronaszn. Not sure how much that affects the difficulty of this class, but I had prof livesay and it was fairly tough. He was a great prof overall, but a lot of the shorthand notation he used nobody was fully familiar with and he acted like it was common knowledge when he'd write those hieroglyphics on the board lol. I crammed the exams bc i had other difficult classes to cater to, but I'd like to say i did fine. Just make sure you do the practice problems and try to not let this class sit on the backburner like i did. study frequently, bc a lot of this class is very new in terms of notation. its like learning another language kinda. a bunch of proofs too. however, once you get that down its pretty straightforward

Probably the easiest math class I've ever taken at UCR. The class is mostly focused on logic and proofs as opposed to raw computation but they're super easy to learn. I rarely attended lectures or discussions and got a nearly perfect score on the final.

Just do the homework and the quizzes, and the exams aren't too difficult. Had a great TA, Matt O'Dell. Helped tremendously. Professor would tell him to give us a quiz, and he would, but everyone failed, so he allowed us to take it home and redo it. Projects aren't too difficult, just show decent effort and you'll get a 100%
Just attend discussions; lectures are basically optional.

Took this class for math minor. Midterm (mainly computational) was easy but later half of the course had alot of theory and conceptual stuff. Avoid Prof Rush, gives raw score of a B to a C, which doesn't make any sense...
Easy class, homework is online and takes about 20 minutes to do. The tests are just like the sample tests and the only mildly challenging test was the final.

I had Schmidt, Karl and he didn't really provide with anything online (iLearn). You have to go to his lecture because you won't have any notes or material (except the textbook if you find it online). His lecture is constant writing; all of the theorems and definitions. A big portion of his midterm is like true and false question and an explanation instead of solving it.

Discussion twice a week. The math itself isn't that hard but you have to justify your answer for some exam questions which requires knowing some theorems and what things actually mean rather than just memorizing a formula. This kinda messed a lot of people up. Quizzes weekly like every other math class, homework is online so you have to buy a subscription.
Easy material, hard tests

Took it with Samuelson, midterm was easy since the midterm practice was similar. Was told final would be similar to the practice final. There were 5 questions out of 13 that we never covered in the final practice or in discussion.

Do NOT take it with Samuelson. While he is a knowledgeable in the subject he's a very bland lecturer. The midterm wasn't too bad but there were at least 4-5 questions that were not previously discussed on the final. Take it with someone else and it shouldn't be difficult.

Ziv Rav is a smart guy if you understand his lectures. Teaches the class conceptually (keep in mind), but his midterm/ final are easy AS LONG AS YOU GO TO CLASS. You don't have to pay attention; the textbook is already good enough to teach you, but he does tell you what kinds of questions will be on the midterm/final exam. He will provide practice midterm/final, but only 60-70% of the questions on there will be similar on the actual midterm/final; the other 40-30% is from when he tells you in lecture. Homework was on MatLab, very easy to do. Easy class, just show up to class
Class is very easy, the midterm is a carbon copy of the sample except a couple of numbers are changed. As long as you do the homework and go to discussion you should be fine.
Very chill overall
[COVID-19 ERA] MATH031 wasn't too bad, tests not proctored only, use internet -> easy A. Final was made optional due to #BLM protests.

I had professor Yunied. He was alright in my opinion. I usually just go to the TA for more help since I thought she was more clear in teaching the material. Exams were usually only about 3-5 questions. So many theorems to know. But it's not that bad if you truly understand the proofs. Ended up with an A in the class just by completing all the homework and getting an A on the one midterm.
Easy class, material learned in this is not very hard

Take Professor Samuelson's class if you can. I had him fall 2020 and he was very understanding of the whole online schooling situation as our grade was only based on matlab and written homework. Highly recommend

I took this class with Xin Yang and I gotta say, this class was too easy. It's hard to fail this class unless you consciously avoid doing the work. He makes the practice quizzes, midterm, and final identical to the real ones. Because of this, there was no need to attend lecture or discussions, which aren't mandatory.

Took the class with prof Xin yang and he was amazing!! He thoroughly taught the subject, and always made sure we understood. He always encourages students to email him questions or attend office hours and is very kind. His sample midterm and final is almost identical to the real midterm and final. Take his class, it’s an easy A!!

I had this with Patricio Candela. This class is not the standard math class where you calculate stuff. It is more focused on theorems and T/F questions. If you want an A in this class, be prepared to study and memorize all the theorems. The calculation part is the easy part so don't focus too much on those. Be prepared to pay $60 for mymathlab.
Easy math class. Don't underestimate final
Literally everyone else I have talked to said this class was super easy, it was one of the hardest maths I have taken. Avoid Daniel Guan at ALL COSTS.
The class as a whole is fairly simple. The midterm average was a 90% for all three sections. Nonetheless, the final was a bit more difficult compared to the midterm, so do not underestimate it.

Extremely easy class until the last chapter. Written homework and quizzes are worded odd and semi-ambiguous on what they ask. Take Zhixian Zhu as she has a clear passion for teaching and will go over step-by-step on difficult problems.
Relatively easy and straightforward math class as long as you know your calculus fundamentals i.e. techniques of integration and derivatives.
Had Diaz. Exams were generally like his quizzes and HW, nothing like his lectures (bc he made-up the problems as he lectured).Very simple. Mainly integration and derivatives.

This class was pretty hard for me, mostly because I couldn't wrap my head around the processes behind it. Read the book, Schaum's Outlines of Differentials is well written and helps out a lot if your professor sucks.
Yunied sucks tbh. Makes everything harder than it needs to be because it “stimulates” his brain

If you don't get an A, you either made some really dumb mistakes along the way or you need to reevaluate how you tackle college courses. As a UC transfer, this course was tied with the easiest course I have ever taken.

Super easy class with Zhixian Zhu! Recommend this professor. Material was a bit intimidating at first, but gets easy once you get the hang of the class. The averages for the final and midterm were a high B.

Take Qixuan Wang. Written HW is graded by completion, midterm and final were only 4 problems and she tells you what will be on them. There is webwork most weeks but they only have a handful of problems (and the worst 2 are dropped). Posts slides but doesn't include solution to examples, which doesn't really matter because the material itself is very easy. You would have to actually try if you wanted to fail.

I had Savanna Gee, and she has been my favorite professor at UCR so far (after 4 quarters). She makes the content very easy to understand. Just take the lessons one day at a time, do some practice, and you'll get 100% on the final. If you want to get ahead, look over Linear, Bernoulli, Exact, & Homogeneous differential equations. If you haven't taken Linear Algebra, you gotta understand the Wronskian.

I took the class with Scott Atkinson, and I thought that the class was relatively difficult considering the fact that I did not take calculus for 2 years. It was difficult to get concepts at first. I had to do several problems from the book in addition to doing the online homework. Do not underestimate the midterm and final.

Had PoNing. Make sure to study for inexact differential equations, cauchy euler differential equations, mixing word problems, and newton's law of cooling as these are the hardest concepts in the class. Overall, class wasn't too difficult.

Optimization: Taken with Ali Pakzad.  Midterm was very easy.  Did not go to class once after the midterm and still ended up with an A-.  Just do the practice problems on the notes and HW and you should be fine.

Professor Tucker taught the class pretty well. Has a standard grading system, so no curves but that already tells you that the class is easy. Provides practice midterm and final prior to the test which are identical. Discussion worksheets = easy true and false. Homeworks are tedious, but they help with your learning.
(covid era) Took it with Henry Tucker. I hated this class, didn't understand anything. Somehow got an A+

Math144 is set theory. I took it with Brian Benson who is very enthusiastic and passionate about the class. The material itself starts off not too bad but in my experience quickly became very abstract and difficult to understand. Homework, midterm, and final were all graded pretty strictly but the curve is generous. All around, a decently hard class

This is basically supposed to be an intro to proofs class. Took it with Schultz. He doesn't use ilearn but instead uploads files to a directory which you have to check regularly since you aren't notified when he adds something new. Lectures were hard to sit through. Honestly I relied on my TA to get me through this class, he did a very good job of explaining the material. Schultz would post a lot of practice problems which I would then go ask the TA how to do them. We were graded on a midterm, 3 quizzes, and a final. Big curves, 64-84 was a B on his midterm lol. I think Math/cs011 would be good prep for this class.

Math 146A is Ordinary Differential Equations and mostly covers slightly more intricate problems as compared to Math046. IMO the class was straight forward and the tests were not too difficult although the HW can be time consuming.

Eeaaasy. Took it with Moradifam. As long as you do the hw yourself you should be able to pass the exams. Some of the exam questions were exactly the same as hw problems. He gives a certain number of problems in exams and you can choose one to not answer. No quizzes. The first half is basically the end of math031 again, just finding Eigenvalues and Eigenvectors. Second half is a bit new, you have to draw phase portraits which seems daunting at first but it really isn't that bad if you have the right professor explain it to you. I'm not sure if exams were curved bc some people got perfect scores on the midterm but if you do better on the final he'll drop your midterm. He really just wants students to pass.

Feng Xu is a terrible professor: doesn't reply to emails, recommends you to drop the class without helping you, no way to cushion your grade. 40% midterm, 60% final, no curve. Though he goes through SIMILAR examples that will be on the midterm/final, but only SIMILAR examples, not exact type of questions. TA carried the course, but he doesn't really care about his students. Very inaccessible.

The homework was a lot more difficult than the tests, but Dr. Costello provides you with practice tests from previous years that really help you prepare. The most difficult material for me was the probability.
Be prepared to do a lot of programming in Matlab. If you do all of your assignments on time, you should be able to get an A, it's really hard to get anything lower than an A.

ACTUALLY DO THE HOMEWORK. If you truly understand the concepts of the homework you'll breeze through the midterms. If you have Princevac be warned the final will be the factor that determines whether you pass the weeder course or not.

You cover the basics of the whole ME curriculum in this one class. Two midterms, one final. You need to do good on at least one midterm because the final ends up killing everyones grade. There is a class curve at the end, but you need to make sure you make the original cutoff for a passing grade. I had stahovich so the cutoff was a 62% for a C. The majority of the class does fail however. 

Homework will take a good 6-8 hours to complete, quizzes are really bad, and you're expected to spend the majority of your time on this class.

Stahovich was a good professor.
This was probably the hardest class I have taken so far (entering 2nd year), so STUDY UP AND DONT SLACK. I barely made it through with a C, but most of my friends did not

Hands down the most difficult weedout course in engineering: they told us on day 1 that only a third of us were expected to get above a C (there is no curve for Princevac), 60% of my class failed. ME2 is designed to make you think like an engineer, not teach you material, which trips up a LOT of people... questions are based on “figure out how to solve the problem” instead of “plug numbers into an equation”. No equation sheets, majority symbolic (mass m1, etc) and only simple calculators, all about your ability to solve problems. If you’re into that, ME2 will be your favorite underclassman course; if not, join the 60%.
Material isn't particularly hard, there is just a lot of info that is covered and the test problems tend to be fairly complex. Your set up is more important than the actual calculations.

You are going to be surprised when you take this class in your first or second year because it take a lot more effort to get good grades than other lower div classes. It probably exists just to scare off students and make them feel ME is not right for them. I sure wish someone told me this class would be so disgusting beforehand because I was definitely not ready for it.

I took this class with Princevac. Class is difficult because of content and heavy emphasis on exam scores, only about 7 A's my year out of a class of 80+. Huge help if you take PHYS040B concurrently (a lot of the topics align such as buoyant forces, and efficiency).

What helped me the most to get an A is having access to 100% correct answers from Chegg or solution keys from previous years. Having accurate solutions helped in two ways: one, saved my homework grade and, two, gave me the right answers to study from when it came to the exam time. Midterm 1, 4/5 problems were seen previously in either homework or quizzes. Midterm 2, 3/5 problems were seen already. Go to office hours to check if your solutions are 100% correct, so you don't miss any points on the exam. Outside of his lectures, you should start applying the principles in the real world and think, "what are the forces acting on this system?" or "Why does this work/built this way?". Ultimately this class should start to make you think like an engineer. Keep in mind this class is supposed to be somewhat enjoyable, and stay humble because it only gets harder from here.

Im a CE major, took the class for the "other" engineering requirement
if you dont want to go into ME or you didnt do too well in physics then this class will be HARD otherwise you should be fine

I'm an MSE and this class was a struggle. I pushed all of my other classes to the side for this class. Tons of time put in outside of class to understand the concepts that Stahovich zooms through in lecture. If you love ME, physics, and have a good understanding of MATH010A ahead of time, you'll be fine.

Prof. Eskandari taught the class very well. HW were easy, quizzes were her lecture notes. 2 Midterms; midterms represented of homework problems and lecture example problems. Final were problems from practice final. Every time she says hint hint or wink wink, that's an indication you'll see that problem either on a quiz, midterm, or final. Take her hints seriously if you want an A. Also go to her office hours for extra credit. Great professor

Difficult if you have no coding experience whatsoever but you do get used to the syntax as the quarter progresses. Attend the labs and ask the TAs for any questions as that's apparently your substitution for office hours. Don't slack off on the final as it was pretty difficult if you don't review for it. It was a mix of hand calculations and writing code by hand. There was a design project due at the end of the quarter. It was pretty difficult so start early. While it is something you can do in 3 days, it is not worth the stress.

Many MEs hate coding or have no experience with it, and ME18 (Intro to MatLab) isn’t meant to teach those skills. Thus, if you come in hoping to touch MatLab as little as possible, or are playing catchup with coding, good luck... best to study ahead by learning Python (lots of great tutorials online) as the syntax has a number of similarities. Sawyer is a babe, but he means it when he says to start the design project early: it’s pretty complex and will devastate novice programmers. Beyond that barrier, ME18 is a chill A :)

I had Dr. Tom Stahovich for this class. He barely answered questions and his assignments were littered with mistakes. I have never been more irritated with a class. Lab assignments took hours. No exams besides the final (which was optional in the end). He had intended to have a half paper half matlab exam and was only stopped from doing that because students didn’t have printers to use. Strongly recommend taking someone else for this class. I learned nothing from him just figured things out on my own and with the TA’s help.

Took it with Venkatram aka "Venky" Fall 2020. Transfer students with no coding experience / MATLAB experience beware, he will expect you to teach yourself coding. His grading system is whack. The TA and other students are teaching the class at this point. No one knows how he grades the labs. However, if you are good at math/manipulating physics equations, and know coding, it's an easy A.

description: INTRODUCTION TO COMPUTATIONAL MODELING IN MECHANICAL ENGINEERING

comments.comment: Took it the first time the class was being offered. ME018 was split into 18A and 18B beginning Fall 2018. This class involves a lot of theorem. You really need to understand the theorem, not just the formulas, or you will fail the class. You will have homework every week -- do not slack off on these. The homework will help you understand the material on the exams (2 midterms and 1 final). There are also quizzes almost every week in discussion. In addition, there was a project due at the end of the quarter. Start the project early cause it's something you can not procrastinate. In fact, a majority of the class didn't finish the project. Class had a huge curve at the end but I'm guessing it was because we were the first ones to take it so be wary. There may not be any more curves for future classes.

There's no official textbook for the class, but looking into some dynamics and fluid mechanics books will certainly be helpful. If taking this with professor Sundarajan, beware of a LOT of homework. Our first midterm had a 50% average score.

Many MEs hate coding or have no experience with it, and ME18 (Intro to MatLab) isn’t meant to teach those skills. Thus, if you come in hoping to touch MatLab as little as possible, or are playing catchup with coding, good luck... best to study ahead by learning Python (lots of great tutorials online) as the syntax has a number of similarities. Sawyer is a babe, but he means it when he says to start the design project early: it’s pretty complex and will devastate novice programmers. Beyond that barrier, ME18 is a chill A :)

Sundar literally combines every engineering topic into this course (heat transfer, fluids, mechanics, statics, etc). You need an extremely strong math foundation going in and good work ethics if you want to pass. Sundar is extremely hard but will make one hell of an engineer out of you.

Taken with Professor Sundar. Ignored all of my classes and put all of my focus on this class. I didn't think it was too bad, and it would have been worse in person. Still a really difficult class though.
The math can be very challenging and hard to grasp at first. You need to study. Matlab is important but barely relevant to final grade.
A lot of math, linear algebra and differential equations. I took it with sundar, he expects us to do 2 projects, but doesnt really go over them
Took it with Sundar. He writes very fast. Excellent professor. Assigns a lot of hw. Exams and project pretty intense.

description: INTRODUCTION TO MEDIA AND CULTURAL STUDIES

comments.comment: Ruhi Khan was the professor and she has made an intro class pretty hard. There are a bunch of readings and she is so freaking opinionated and won't listen to anyone else's opinions. The midterms are not exactly that hard, but man that teacher is brutal. I don't recommend taking it with her, she makes everything so much complicated than it should be and when I went to office hours for a paper, the ta and the professor both said different things so it was extremely confusing. She complained for a whole class on how bad our essays were and  she grades pretty hard.
Any mcs class with Anderson is an easy A

Half of the course content is a rehashing of MCS001 and the rest of the course content is media theories. Professor Su is flexible and understanding. Your grade is based on the midterm (multiple choice) and final (2 essay questions). The only downside of this course lectures arent reuploaded, but fairly simple class.

Took with Anderson during Covid Winter 2021 and it was pretty easy. All lectures were prerecorded and discussions aren't mandatory. The lectures are kind of boring and long but would have probably been better in person. No final exam, but there's a final project which is making a blog. Do all of the lecture pps and only need to do 4 discussion pps for full pp credit. Easy A

description: INTRODUCTION TO CONTEMPORARY CRITICAL ISSUES IN ART

comments.comment: took online with professor larios, you can probably get away with not doing anything for this class but you'll understand the material more if you actually attend class. lectures were pretty heavily discussion-based so it was mostly us talking about the readings/videos but you don't have to talk at all if you're not comfortable. in short, the class was easy and the material is very thought-provoking but can be hard to digest sometimes.

description: CULTURAL STUDIES: HISTORICAL AND CONTEMPORARY PERSPECTIVES

comments.comment: attend review sessions before the midterm and final and you should be okay for the exams.

Midterms are specific about the readings and lecture notes. Go to lecture, she (setsu) tells you what is going to be on the midterm. She seems nice but is kinda unapproachable because she judges you so hard. Rachel (TA) was the best!! she replied fast on emails, graded things on time, and created summaries for the readings (i read those summaries for midterms instead of doing the readings)

description: MAJOR FIGURES IN FILM AND MEDIA
DISNEY: PRODUCING RACE, GENDER AND SEXUALITY
INTERSECTIONS OF MEDIA AND POPULAR CULTURE
SPECIAL TOPICS IN TECHNOCULTURE AND DIGITAL MEDIA
EXISTENTIALISM IN LITERATURE, FILM, AND CULTURE

comments.comment: Hsiao has pretty simple exams.  Watch out for his free response questions cuz they take longer than you might think.  Pretty fair for 50 mins and no cumulative final.  Uses TopHat for extra credit and assigned a powerpoint group presentation in discussion.  Very straightforward class overall.

Interesting class but Wenbo Ma had really hard exams & her TA was a super. She had the audacity to get mad at us when the average was mid 50s.. don't you know the common denominator between all of us is having YOU as a professor?

Lab reports are easy but long and tedious, so don't make the same mistake I did and start late. Make sure you format them correctly. You can expect to pull an all-nighter if you start the night before. Coffey grades somewhat harshly on the scientific paper for some strange reason, so expect points off even if you show it to him and he gives the ok. The midterms are easy if you pay attention in class (no final). Go for the extra credit points!
Francis Moore is a super nice violinists. I have her as my violin instructor. Just do the work and put some effort and you'll get an A
Super Easy A. I took it with Frances Moore and it filled my humanities breadths. Attendance is mandatory tho.

description: POPULAR MUSIC CULTURES OF THE UNITED STATES

comments.comment: Took it with Prof Deborah Wong (amazing prof makes class enjoyable). There are 4 quizzes (not cumulative) and 1 essay, no final and no homework. She uses PollEverywhere for participation so attendance is needed (or you could just be on PollEverywhere all the time).

Literally dont take the class. Everyone says that its easy but its NOT. I had to S/NC the class because I was so close to getting a C. No matter how much you study, she will quiz you on random stuff in the textbook.

A fun and easy class! I definitely learned a lot more than I thought I would. Dr. Wong is very engaging and is enthusiastic about the material and makes sure to teach it with a very non-white-centric viewpoint to make sure we get the full "story" and context of American popular music of days gone by. 1 1000-word paper on a biopic of her choice (we did Selena), and 4 non-cumulative quizzes (the last quiz is the "final" and covered 1970s-onwards) - the criteria for the biopic paper is easy to understand and the quizzes are extremely straight-forward. Discussion is nice, we sometimes talked about stuff that wasn't covered in class but is in the textbook, and each discussion before the next quiz was dedicated solely to review.

Took this class with Professor Wong. Decently harder than I expected. It's not that the material was difficult to comprehend, it's that there's 4 quizzes in the class and each has 15 questions and is worth fifteen percent of your grade. So getting a few questions wrong means you're screwed. And it's pretty easy to mess up since some questions are based on memory of what an artist looks like or a certain part of a song out of a required 30 songs that are required. Study for quizzes, go to discussion. This was my lowest grade of the quarter, but I got an A.
Ez pz. Go to discussion, don't procrastinate the essay, exams is stuff on lectures. You should probably at least read the textbook pages.
Took it with Chavez, exams were fair but a little bit on the hard side. There were two midterms and 1 final
I took Xochilt Chavez online, it was not that hard, but it was very disorganized.

description: GENDER, SEXUALITY, AND MUSIC IN CROSS-CULTURAL PERSPECTIVES
AMERICAN MUSICAL SUBCULTURES: A GENEALOGY OF ROCK

comments.comment: You don't even have to read for this class just memorize the slides and listen to the lectures. Took it with Andreja Novakovic

Really easy class. The readings are basically useless because all the material you need for tests comes from the slides. Professor Novakovic isn't challenging anyone that much in this class since many people just take it to fill a breadth requirement. Just listen to what she says during lectures
Novachovic: If you attend the lectures and pay attention, you can succed. Paying attention and reading the passage ensures an easy B+ or A
Don't take it with Keller. He teaches the subject in a strange way and is difficult to listen to.
Professor Wood is a great professor. No mid term, no final, just 3 papers throughout the quarter.

Took with Dr. Joshua Wood. Pretty straightforward class. 3 essays, and each essay added an extra prompt on top of the previous one. (Ex. If essay one asked you to explain an argument, the second essay asked you to do the same, and give a counterargument.) Essays were graded by the TA, No Midterm or Final Exam

Had Joshua Wood. This class really shouldn't have been that hard, but I had a picky TA who didn't use the professor's grading scale for the essays. No midterm, no final- just papers. Go to your TA's office hours to find out what exactly they are looking for in the essays. Barely have to show up to lecture

Took with John Fischer, extremely easy, your grade really depends on your TA, was able to get extra credit points, read the lecture slides and you're fine, you don't need to do the readings, no paper just 2 midterms and a final; show up to discussions
The class itself was fairly easy. You don't even need to read. The people who determine your "fate" are your T.A'S. Everything is graded by your T.A.

Taken with Luca Ferrero. He is a good professor, but he over-explains a bunch of concepts for most who are taking this class as a breadth course. The quizzes are TOUGH. You have 3 hours and it is technically open note, but its nearly impossible ton find the answer in a straightforward manner. Very weird grading scale - TA's do literally determine your grade and fate so be nice to them.

Took it with professor Swanson. Just 3 papers, rarely attended lecture all slides are online but ask the TAs for help if you want a good grade on your paper. It seems straightforward but they have high expectations for them
Took it with Dr. Wood & very helpful if you go to lectures, the exams and finals weren't too bad as long as you went to lecture
took it with Swanson, just 3 paper, nothing hard

I took it with Wood. I would say, if you can connect with what's being said at lecture with the readings, this is an okay class. Somewhat lots of reading (ranging from like a short article to a chpt) for each class but overall, I think it was actually okay. The lectures and readings are kinda interesting and I didn't feel drowsy/kept up with the lectures. Would recommend if you're okay with reading/looking at things from someone else's POV

description: ETHICS AND THE MEANING OF LIFE

comments.comment: Professor (Coleen) was very poor at using time effectively in class. Often rambled/discussed some meaningless corner case for our content. Course material itself isnt too hard however. Book is also somewhat verbose and reading it can be a challenge. Quizzes are 90% of your grade (10% each, 9 total, during discussion). I HIGHLY suggest getting Akshay Ganesh for TA. He releases his personal notes the day before his discussion and they are extremely helpful. There are in class quizzes which are worth around 5% of your grade. The class is curved to a B-. As long as you do well on the weekly quizzes in your discussion, you'll do fine.

Professor Londen was really nice. The only way to prepare for the quizzes and to get an A honestly is to meet up with him during office hours and ask him to give some more examples of the sorts of questions he wants us to answer. Show up to lecture!
