Prof. Londen teaches this class and is super nice and willing to help, you just have to communicate. This class was very difficult because you are learning a new skill. The class is curved though so I believe a 50% was actually a C. If you want to pass the class with an A which is 100% possible, start off strong and go to office hours starting week 2 before your first exam. There is a test every week so go to office hours every week because everything is built ontop of everything so if you dont understand something from a previous week it will harm you the entire quarter. The TAs and prof all grade each individual exam together so they try to give you as many points as possible. Final exam is optional.
Since I was in honors, I had the professor as my TA in discussion. Very helpful and easy class. Got an A. It was more of an online class
very easy to learn everything, the end of the quarter is where it gets a bit hard, but nothing scary.

The professor Nagashima himself is a nice guy who is trying his best to teach. The class however I found a bit difficult. In the beginning the class was very easy to follow and was going at a steady pace Then out of nowhere towards the last couple of weeks we get thrown these difficult concepts which had little relation to what we learned in the beginning. Must have time to study outside of class or you will bomb the second midterm and final. I managed an A on both midterms but I invested quite a bit of time in study groups etc. It’s passable but as a breadth class it was a bit stressful.

The class can get confusing if you have Michael Nelson but as long as you go to every lecture and disscusion and pay attention then you should do fine. 4-10 problems for homework a week but some hw sets may take a few hours. The concepts can be a little hard to grasp but the classwork is fairly low. Never studies for both midterms and I got an 88% on both.

Took it with Michael Nelson. This guy is so confusing in his lectures, and he wrote the book, which is worded just as he talks. Hard class tbh. Got an A minus because the final was hard as hell, even after getting a 94 and 100 on my two midterms, and over 100% on my homework.

this class is definitely hit or miss; like either you'll find it super easy and get an A+ or you won't understand jackshit. if you're familiar with cs this class won't be too bad bc it's basically all boolean like true/false. but prof nelson is definitely not a good teacher and is super confusing. if you have mcdonald as your ta you'll be fine tho.

I had Professor Erich Reck, the materials might be difficult depending on how much you can comprehend logic, but the class is relative easy to pass. You get 3 tries for homework, extra credit problems on (most) quizzes and midterms. It is an easy A if you do homework, attend discussion, and watch lecture

There's only 2 mandatory essays. 4 if you count the first one, which is a practice essay to get feedback and stuff, while the fourth one replaces your lowest essay score (provided that it was above a 70%? I believe). I got an A- but you still have to work for your grade, especially since the readings are pretty difficult to process BUT the professor (I had Joshua Wood) will give you outlines of the articles, so it's easier to understand. He's also pretty funny in the slack channel. One girl was like, "Where is the 10th assignment?" when we only had two essays, and he was like "you're scaring people" LOL. Make sure you don't procrastinate on your essays! My TA liked a direct approach to writing, so be concise with your wording and make it easy to understand.

Took it with Dr. Joshua Wood during Fall 2020. No mandatory lectures and he gives you an free version of the textbook online. Dr. Wood is super sweet and his lectures (if you do decide to go) are essentially a discussion about the assigned readings. If you choose not to go, he offers recorded lectures and notes as supplements.  Homework are the assigned readings but you don't really need to read any of them unless you're choosing that specific one to write the essay about. No exams only four essays two of which are mandatory; the first one is a practice one and the last one is an extra credit opportunity. Each essay increases in page limit; the first one 1-2, second 2-3, etc. Essays are super easy and basically an analysis essay on the argument of the document. TAs grade the essays so it really depends on them. I had Gustavo for my discussion and he was pretty easy going, attending was also not mandatory. The only assignment was a discussion question regarding the material due every Wednesday and in the discussion he'd address those questions.

description: PHILOSOPHICAL ISSUES OF RACE AND GENDER
PHILOSOPHY, FILM, AND REFLECTIVE POPULAR CULTURE

comments.comment: Take Gabor. He's absolutely amazing
Hai Bo Yu doesn't help with MasteringPhysics and the textbook isn't good.

Professor Hai Bo Yu was a nice guy, but his accent made it hard to understand sometimes, and he mostly just read off of premade lecture slides straight from the textbook. I learned everything from doing the homework and from watching videos online, not from him.
Exams are unpredictable. Avoid Joshua Lui. Other professors are much better.
Joshua Lui is okay, but exams were a bit hard. Allows you a formula sheet.
Easy homework and clickers. Hard tests

Had Yongtao Cui. Was concerned since he has 0 ratings online so I didn't know what to expect. However, he's a decent professor. Exams are quite hard, midterms averages about 40-50%, same as final. Important to not fall back in this class as the material is quite hard to understand without going to class. I scored 20-25% above exam averages and that got me an A.

Difficult because many students are balancing this class with CHEM 008A. Definitely recommend you to read up on each chapter during the weekend before the lecture. It helps you understand the material early on. I also recommend that you do the practice problems in the textbook for additional practice outside of HW. If you have Peng Wei, I recommend to go to office hours and ask him for help especially if you're falling behind.

Took it with YongTao Cui. A very caring professor but a hard class. Averages for exams were about 40% but there was a fat curve at the end. Definitely do practice questions and make sure you understand the concepts.

I took this class with Beyermann in the summer of 2020. Would not recommend. His tests are difficult. Furthermore, the hw he assigns aren't similar to what the tests looks like. Granted that this class was in 5 weeks so take this with a grain of salt.

Took the class with Beyermann over the summer, would not recommend with him because it was my first time taking physics so I was really lost, midterms were really hard 30-60% averages, final was doable. Try finding someone else first

"Never took PHYS, but taking it with Professor John Ellison was the best choice ever! He is very patient in answering questions during lecture, reexplains concepts that are hard/what he thinks most students struggle with, and is very very understanding of the pandemic conditions! His midterm is very similar to his practice exams and homework is difficult so if you struggle with that don't worry to much just make sure to understand the practice exams and concepts. Final is NOT cumulative so that helps too. Does online clickers for credit so class is kinda mandatory and I never read his reading notes before lecture, but doing that would've helped me .
PHYS 2A is known as a weeder class, but I learned a lot and walked out with a B+ because of Prof Ellison so definitely take it with him!"
Take Wimpenny for his good curve, by the class is still challenging no matter who you take it with. It's hard to understand what exactly is going on most of the time.
Wimpenny is boring but he has written exams so partial credit is possible
Mulligan is a good prof.  Look through all his slides and practice.  Big curve for class overall.
Had Mulligan. Very chill and relaxed with the course. Curve/cutoffs are very generous. Try to take him if possible, he didnt fail anyone!
Alot of forumlas to memorize. IF you get Jory Yamorff make sure you study, but he is a fair grader. Decent curve but not huge.
Mohideen has large curves with the avg being a B. Lots of formulas to memorize but not to difficult if you look at the units.
Took the class with Harry Tom over the summer, would not recommend, got an A+ but I had to sell my soul cause his midterm, quizzes, and final were some of the hardest things I've ever done.
Avoid Anderson. Google "UCSD 1C final exam" and there's over 100 practice problems from the equivalent course at UCSD
Simple class, simple work, and extremely high grade boosts in Barton's class.

(Took online in Winter 2021 with John Barton) This was the easiest of the Physics 2 series for me. Content-wise, it has some topics from gen chem, which makes it familiar and a bit easier to understand. His exams were all multiple choice and open note. Quite a few problems were similar to practice exams and it was not difficult to do well in the class as long as you know how to do practice exam questions and the lecture examples. A lot of it is just knowing how to use the formulas/equations, so sometimes just knowing how to do math can help you solve the problems! Since the exams are on the easier side, he doesn't curve much so 90 = A, 75 = B, and 60 = C, but if averages are low, he may change the cutoffs slightly. The professor you take for physics in general will determine how well you do since some professors give more difficult exams, but will curve or adjust cutoffs accordingly.
Good grades if you do the labs properly.  Easy final.

They may have changed it, but I took Fall 2018 and the labs were literally the WORST experience I've had at UCR. However, the final was really easy and there was a curve so it isn't hard to get an A, just an annoying class to take.

I think it is imperative to read the lab before you come to class so you have somewhat of an idea to complete the lab. It will help save you a lot of points and time. It also helps to ask the TA for certain sections in the lab. In addition, final assessment was done online (as a timed iLearn exam). Honestly, if you are well prepared for the lecture and know how to do the labs, you should be able to ace the final exam. P.S. You are allowed to use your lab notebook during quizzes and the final assessment, so write down those formulas and concepts if you need it (as a cheat sheet). :)
If you don't know lecture stuff, it's hard to follow along.  Final is easy if you know where to put equations.
The exams are mainly theory based now with few calcs. Write down impt in your lab notebook and chill.
Write everything in your lab notebook and the final is a piece of cake.  Labs weren't too difficult either.

I had Prof. Mobasher. He curved the course almost a whole letter grade after the final. The class was all theory of the Big Bang and the events after it.(Almost five weeks were spent talking abt the Big Bang) No math involved.
Homework is easy since you can just google it but the material is hard to understand if I could go back in time I wouldn't take this class again.
There's a lot of difficult content but Mobasher curves the tests greatly

Love Mobasher as a professor but the material is dense and hard to understand for non science people. Final and midterm is worth 25% of overall class and hw is 50%. Do with that what you must, but I personally would not take again not worth the stress.
Had it with Prof. Mobasher. Curves the test and google is your friend for homeworks and tests.
Took the class online with Prof. Mobasher. Super easy class, all homework could be found online, and both the midterm and final were open notes.
This class the exactly equivalent to AP Physics 1(but they don't give credit for some reason). Pay attention during rotation(moment of inertia, rotational kinetic energy). It's harder than it looks.

You definitely need to read the textbook thoroughly and watch a ton of Khan Academy videos or else you're going to do really bad in the class. One midterm and one final. No quizzes. Do your homework. Mastering Physics is a pain, especially with significant figures, but that will definitely make or break your grade.
If you have any physics background (high school, etc) this class will be easy peasy.
Most people weren't Reedy for the final. Overall pretty easy class; homework, clickers, 1 exam, 1 final. Just follow along with the class & know how to use the equations.
Professor Reddy. Overall grade is curved at the end.
Honestly, this class was harder than 40B and 40C for me. I got a C in 40A while I got a B+ in 40B and an A in 40C... Make sure you do a ton of practice problems and read the book.

Read the textbook, do a lot of practice problems. Bombed the final and got a C in the class but I also didn't do most of the homework and stopped going to lecture consistently. Just keep up and you'll be fine. Curved at the end; Reddy

Took this class with Reddy. Max all your other scores because you never know how the curve will affect you. Got a B- on the midterm  and then proceeded to get a D+ on the final and barely ended with a flat A so I got lucky solely because I made sure everything else was near 100%. As for the labs, don't just read the lab manuals beforehand - try and set up your lab pages/tables and answer the questions too. And if they don't provide excel spreadsheets to do calculations in, make them yourself because it'll save you a lot of time, especially if your TA is strict.

basically like AP Physics 1 with some other topics included and excluded. If you've taken AP Physics 1 and put in the work, this should be an easy A. No quizzes, only need to participate in 80% of clicker questions for a 100%, labs were sort of confusing at times but if you understand labs then you will be an A on the lab final.

took it with Reddy. his lectures are boring and all he does are problems. huge curve i got a 45 on the midterm and 81 on the final 79 on the lab portion 100 on discussion 97 in homework and it came out to a solid B+ with the curve
In discussion, the TA gives optional physics questions that are far harder to solve than those in class. Instead of doing everything, learning to solve these will ensure you succeed!
Professor Thomas Kulman was chill and funny for this class, homework was easy but the midterm was kinda hard. Overall alright class

I CANNOT STRESS THIS ENOUGH DO NOT GET MICHAEL ANDERSON UNLESS YOU WANT TO TEACH URSELF EVERYTHING. It's not worth it either switch profs or drop him. He does not teach anything nor does he explain anything in lectures. His style of "teaching" is to give a worksheet and have u do it on ur own. He does not provide answers for said worksheet nor explain how to do any of the problems ever. If you know physics by all means take the class for the units but if not avoid Anderson at all costs.
Screw Michael Anderson, worst professor I ever had at UCR, avoid him at all costs for any physics classes.
Tsai is a terrrible professor but huge curves
homework was difficult. Practice exam was almost exactly the same as real exams. Hardest of the 40 series imo

I had Boerge as my professor and would honestly recommend him to anyone. He posts his lectures online and is very passionate about Physics + wants everyone to succeed. Make sure to go to his office hours in order to get any clarifications sorted out. If you also have Boerge, he basically covers 99% of the material from the textbook so you do not really have to read (although he will quiz you some concepts from the textbook during clickers).
In terms of the class, if you suffered through 40A, you will definitely suffer through 40B. The midterm was fairly simple, as it only covered about three chapters, but the final will definitely kill everyone's grade (however, it is not cumulative).
Discussions are mandatory and there was a quiz every class -- something not mentioned in the syllabus. According to my TA, 50% of one's discussion grade is based off attendance and the other 50% is based off the quiz grades.
Clickers were not based off participation -- something that is different from 40A. Make sure you attend every class as those points will matter.

The individual concepts and homework aren't too bad, the main difficultly in the class comes from the fact that all 3 professors write 1/3rd of the final and how Mills combines different concepts from the entire course into one question. For example this quarter(winter 2018) he somehow combined pistons, ideal gases, heat of vaporization, and thermodynamics into a single fucking question. Even if you understand the physics behind all these concepts perfectly, his questions feel like a puzzle. As far as I can tell, the other two professors make extremely "easy" straightforward questions and the curve is usually pretty nice. 

In the past, you would want to avoid Mills because he makes the hardest questions and he doesn't teach that well but now that all the professors are making the final, it might actually be beneficial to have him as a professor because you could get used to his madness before the final.
The class is pretty reasonable and doable and the midterm isn't that bad. The final was nothing like any of the practice or homework. It was extremely difficult and ridiculous

Content is relatively straight forward and homework reflects what is taught in class. Quizzes are ripped straight from the homework, so do the HW before discussion. Midterm and final are difficult, but practice exams should prepare you for them. Fat curve at the end of the class.

Most people will have a harder time with this than 40A, so it's important to read the book and make sure you're keeping up with the material. It mainly focuses on waves, but there is some heat transfer involved. I had Igor Barsukov. His tests are pretty hard but the curves are huge, I got a 45% on the midterm, which curved to a B.

Tsai is unbelievably boring. The lectures are legitimately a waste of everyones time, too bad there are clicker questions for points. The lab is shitty, but easy. Online homework is on chegg. Pretty sure I got an A despite missing most lectures. Definitely a self-study class.
Professor Long was so nice but he expects a lot of outside reading and work especially if you wanna do well on the exams. Hardest class in the phys040 series

I had Pryadko, and it's very hard to follow lecture. The textbook was a lifesaver. I would rate this class higher (I ended up rating it a 6), but Pryadko's curve makes it so a 55% is a C-. Without that curve, this class would be a 9 at minimum.
Labs were quite time consuming as the manuals weren't very well written. Not too bad of a class though, just know how to use the formulas and you should be good
Do not take with Long. He makes the tests unnecessarily hard.
About the same difficulty as Phys40A. Took it with Tanedo Winter 2021. If able, take this with Tanedo, he will make your life and physics so much easier.

Took PHYS040B with Tanedo. With Tanedo, this class was super easy. No quizzes, no tests, no midterm, no final. We have to make these weekly videos explaining how to do certain problems from the textbook every week and grade our peers on their videos. i think it's an effective learning format. Tanedo is genuinely such a nice guy and an amazing prof. Highly recommend taking 040B with him if you can. The labs are kinda painful imo, but they aren't too terrible.

try to take with Tanedo. he's the absolute best. no examinations, and he genuinely cares about how you are doing in the class and wants you to learn. grade based on you making explainer videos to show how to solve 2 physics problem given by him every week. made physics easy and entertaining, really is one of the best professors
Much more difficult than 40B.
About the same as 40B, but no practice exams provided means I didn't do as well on the midterms/finals.

The class, itself, is really difficult and I struggled through it the entire quarter. Professor Sales, however, was a wonderful professor and explained the material thoroughly. I honestly recommend having her for your physics professor, even if it isn't for PHYS040C.
Side note, you really need to know the right hand rule for this class or you're going to suffer second half of the quarter.

Requires a bit of studying, but is ultimately not too difficult. Just pay attention in lecture and watch youtube videos to fill in gaps. Just don't take Monday labs as you will have to go over concepts that are taught in lecture later during the week.

Laura Sales was my professor. Very good teaching style, explains things well and does examples in class. Midterm is free response and multiple choice, while final was all multiple choice. I personally found 40C and 40B easier than 40A.

Took with Becker. I found this class a lot more difficult than 40A and 40B since I wasn't used to a lot of the concepts (I also fell behind so lol dont do that). The curves are gonna sharper since there was no helpful practice midterm or a practice final. But, if you score higher on your final than the midterm, the final replaces your midterm which is great!
Topics are tough so put in extra time to learn the concepts. Try understanding the concepts instead of memorizing as Becker tests more on understanding and applying. Much harder than 40B and 40A.

Took it with Yanou Cui. It was her first time teaching it, so she did not offer any practice exams. I personally wouldn’t take it again with her as I don’t like how she explained things. It seemed like all she did was read off lecture slides from the textbook. Her exam questions were also mostly theoretical instead of working with solid numbers.

Laura Sales was very easygoing during Fall 2020. She offered a modest amount of extra credit too. She really cares about the students learning, and overall, she was definitely one of my favorite professors at UCR so far. 4 exams total, each 5 multiple choice questions, and she drops the lowest score. If you're taking EE001A at the same time, you'll see a lot of nice overlap.

Professor Sales. SHE IS THE BEST PROFESSOR IN THE DEPARTMENT. Take this class if you are a non-physics major and would just like a class on physics taught in a casual, chill way. You will definitely learn from her class, and she is a great teacher. But she is also a practical person, and understands that not every one of her students wants to dedicate their entire lives around learning physics.
This class was made unnecessarily hard online, only 1 lecture a week (fall 2020),  a bunch of useless videos and a garbage textbook, if you have prior physics knowledge it is not that hard
Focus on the essays, they are worth the most. Overall super easy
Term paper graded pretty hard by the TAs but the exams were mixed MC/essay and graded very easily along with a curve. Easy A
Prof. Ritchie is so nice and easy. No Midterm just 2 papers, an online quiz, and a final. TA's are really chill

Prof Daniel Biggers online course doesn't require too much, except for mandatory discussions, a term paper, a midterm, and a non-cumulative final. Focus more on the term paper since it's worth as much as the midterm. Attending lecture will help you pass.

DO NOT take with Bruce Bordner. It's a breadth course but he treats the class as if everyone is a polisci major. The midterm is worth 25%, the term paper has to be 8 pages long and is worth 25%, attendance in discussion is worth 20%, and the final is worth 30% but there's 13 pages in the final review that's packed with vocab you need to memorize! Just do yourself a favor and avoid him.

Lectures are pretty boring and the reading is overwhelming. However, the midterm and final are very straightforward and the content is not difficult. If you put in some effort and actually study, getting an A is easy.
Professor Dionne taught this course - super easy, exams are given ahead of time and essay questions are drawn out of a hat. Your preparation matters for the exam. Thats really it

Honestly lecture is kind of interesting and my discussion was too especially if you have Ian. Not hard midterm was just an essay and some term definitions, final was two essays and two essays (fall quarter 2019)
Easy class as long as you put some work in and go to office hours. Professor Dionne is great!

This class is honestly so interesting and fun, it made me want to go into political science. I had Andrew and he kept lectures interesting & funny, really good at explaining things and I was rarely ever lost in the class. I don’t really think you need to do the readings, midterms and finals are accumulative so you can just read the textbook the week of to get more info, otherwise he explains it all in the lectures so no hw either, hw is up to the professor. For mine, we just had to ask a question on week 3,5,7,9 really easy but not in a bad way, made it a relaxing yet interesting class!!

Irrepoglu-Carreras talks way too much; you don't need to write down everything she says. The 2 exams/final and notes are based on the slides/study guides. Reading the textbook helps to clarify the slides but you definitely don't need to do any more than skim the chapters.
If you take this class with prof. Marissa Brookes, it's fairly easy as long as you just show up to lectures and discussion. there's 3 exams + the final exam so one bad grade won't kill you
Prof. D'Anieri knows his stuff. Prof. provides a study guide with the exam questions on it. There are usually 30 questions and 5 will be on the exam. TA's are really picky about the answers
Had Brookes, her exams were hard since they were fill in the blanks and she wanted you to be very specific about things.
I had Brookes, the class was awfully boring and the exams were hard since they were all fill in the blank. The TAs were strict on grading and wanted you to be overly specific.
I would stay clear of Professor D’anieri, it’s not that the material was difficult but the sheer amount of reading and relatively broad study guides made the class a big pain.

Paul D’Anieri is extremely helpful in office hours, intelligent, kind, and has damn good music taste. DO THE READING. you have to know a lot of concepts and how to make a good argument. Overall a great and eye-opening class, just s lot of work

Took it with Paul D’Anieri. He knows what he’s talking about, and is a great lecturer. His office hours help so much and he’s overall just a cool guy. Into music, always plays a song in the beginning of class. A lot of reading, but he wrote the textbook and it’s pretty good. As long as you know the concepts you should be okay. Two midterms and a final. Each midterm has five short answer questions and an essay for 50 minutes, which isn’t as bad as it sounds. The final has the same layout but with an extra essay and 25 more minutes. Loved the class!
no homework or papers, the test were difficult because of the time constraints (50 mins)

Took Irrepoglu-Carreras over Fall 2020 quarter, attendance wasn't required (even in her live session).  Ridiculously easy, her quizzes are graded by completion, not performance, you can just speed run through the quiz and still get 100%.  Her mid-term and final was open book and was not proctored, both were extremely easy.  The class only gets difficult if you have a TA that assigns quizzes on the readings every week, I got lucky and got a chill ass TA (she never assigned quizzes).  Shout out to Bea-Sim!

Professor Irrepoglu-Carreras made course very easy. Grading is based on bi-weekly quizzes that are participation based and 2 take-home exams. All course presentations and materials were easily available. Vocabulary heavy course, but easy to understand.

I had professor irepoglu-carreras and she was really great! there's biweekly quizzes but they're only participation based and don't effect your grade. the midterm and final are take-home and aren't very hard at all, most of the answers you can find in her lectures. other than that, there's readings every week, but they're usually like no more than 12 pages and are pretty interesting!

description: POLITICS OF RACE, IMMIGRATION, AND ETHNICITY IN THE UNITED STATES

comments.comment: Yasemin Irepoglu Carreras taught the class. Tests were very easy. Class had a Midterm, Final, 6-8 page term paper, class participation (random activities), and discussion. No textbook and weekly readings are not really required. Term/vocab heavy.

description: THE PROLIFERATION OF WEAPONS OF MASS DESTRUCTION

comments.comment: Taught by Gregory. Content was not too bad, but there is a lot of writing assignments associated with the course. 1 Midterm, 1 Final, 1 Book Eval, 1 Research Report. One opportunity for Extra Credit (worth 1.5% boost). Needs props because she was very responsive to student needs and adjusted deadlines if asked
Take all the classes you can with Weller. Super slow pace, can get by w/o reading, one midterm, one final group paper. Easy A imo

Course taught by Professor Merolla. Can get by without reading since most of the information is on her lecture slides. Need to purchase TopHat though. One group assignment about GOTV efforts. Not hard at all

description: HUMAN RIGHTS IN THEORY, LAW, AND POLITICS

comments.comment: Taken with Serieux-Lubin. Straightforward asynchronous class with somewhat long video lectures. TA was a bit of a mess and graded wildly, but besides that, the classroom components are easy.

Taken with Cioffi. Dude's exam was hard and his lectures are delivered in a boring fashion. He is SUPER smart though. He sorta drops hints about his exams when he talks so you should pay attention to EVERYTHING he says. 70% of grade is determined through Midterm Essay and Final

Taught by Osorio. Course was very easy, but had a lot of daily assignments (e.g. daily quizzes and readings). Made memes and listened to podcasts. Not taught like how a traditonal law course, but learned some cool stuff. Participation makes or break the grade though
He gives you most of the answers to the test questions every lecture. So I got a B just by studying all the test questions he gave us. Never went to lecture.

Steve Clark is an amazing professor. I didnt even open the book for my two midterms and got an A and a B. Just go to his lectures, a lot of the quiz content is about his anecdotal examples. 10/10 would take again
Rosenbaum is a gem. Easy A. Gives you 20/25 exam questions ahead of time
Very easy for people who aren’t into psychology. Highly recommend taking it for a requirement.

Huffman is amazing at explaining the material and really funny, definitely take it with her if possible. Everything is based on the notes, don't waste time buying the textbook. You'll definitely have to do some studying but most of it is easy

Took it with Dr. Huffman. Good professor especially if you are desiring to take more PSYCH classes. Reading the textbook isn't super super important, so you can probably get away with not reading it because she mentions how theres only like two to three questions on the exam where the information comes from the book. Key to doing well in the class is memorization and understanding the notes she post on iLearn. Lecture is important to as she says things that rewards those students who attend lecture, but can get from a friend. Got a B+ and read the book and went to lecture, but beware of the Neuroscience part, required a lot of memorization but is doable. Note... on her power point there are presenter notes when you download them... OPEN THOSE and study those too.. questions from midterms and final were from there I vividly remember that.

Had Dr. Huffman. There was 2 midterms and they were mostly from lecture slides and a few extra credit questions from the random things that she talks in lectures. You don't really need the textbook since the exams are mostly from lectures

Take this with Huffman. She's funny and actually made me want to come to lecture. Studying required a bit but you can pass without using the textbook at all. Write down some of the weird stuff she says in class, they come up on the test.
prof huffman: easy to get a B, hard to get an A

If you took AP Psych in high school, it is basically a review of that. I never went to class or studied and got a B. I had Dr. Huffman, she's really kind. There's no homework but there are pretty much quizzes every discussion and 2 midterms and a final that make up your grade. Also, she drops the 2 lowest quiz scores

Took it with Professor Steven Clark. Always attend lectures because his exams focus more on what he discusses in class than the book. He posts his slides but they are extremely vague, so it won't be that helpful if you don't pay attention in class.
Easy A with Rosenbaum

took it in the summer with Dr. Huffman, intense 5 weeks. 9 quizzes (lowest one dropped), 1 midterm (average was 87% - 80 multiple choice questions, no backtracking), 1 final exam (80 multiple choice questions, non-cumulative), discussion attendance is mandatory for points, and some zaps & inquiztive assignments weekly. The whole course was on canvas, each week was posted in advance, no required live lecture meetings!
Took it with Huffman. I think overall, it was decently easy. If you followed the textbook, read what you needed to, you could ace the exams. Recommend

Had this class online with Professor Ditta and would highly recommend. She is very passionate about what she teaches, and offers a bunch of extra credit. The assignments themselves are not very difficult. There are weekly assignments for discussion section, and lecture attendance is not mandatory.

Professor Ditta is the best! She made the class flexible and very straightforward. There was 1 final, weekly assignments that are pretty easy, and extra credit quizzes. I'm really going to miss her class because she's just so kind and you can tell she enjoys teaching. Overall, an amazing class!!!

Took this class because everyone said it was easy but I almost failed. I took it with Professor Clark. He was very nice but I just couldn't stay engaged during lectures. His lectures also don't have words with bullet points so it's mostly just listening, which makes it hard for me. He is very approachable and willing to help so that is nice.

Taken with Ditta in Fall 2020. Extremely chill online zoom lectures which I RECOMMEND TAKING NOTES ON (it'll help for the PSYC 001 study guide she releases a week or two before the final). I 100% RECOMMEND DITTA... EXTREMELY HELPFUL AND WANTS TO HELP YOU LEARN THE MATERIAL...LOVES TALKING WITH STUDENTS ABOUT VIDEO GAMES, OTHER TOPICS OUTSIDE OF CLASS AND IN OFFICE HOURS. She gives no midterm as well, only the final, and there are weekly assignments as well as a final project. On another note, she requires 4 hours of "research participation", which is done online. The research consists mostly of taking online quizzes that are used in UCR studies and each one is worth an hour, so do 4 quizzes on the UCR research site for easy completion.

took online with professor ditta, she's great at teaching the material and gives you everything you need to succeed in the class. 1 midterm, 1 cumulative final & a final media project, all free response but it's open note/textbook. there are also lots of extra credit quiz opportunities!
Easier than PSYCH001 imo
Its an ipen notes class
Extremely easy if taught by Prof. Sy. Barely went to lecture and passed with an A
Pretty easy, especially if you have  Dr. Rachel Wu. She does an amazing job breaking everything down. Don't really need the textbook because all of her tests/quizzes are based on the slides!
professor murray makes it fun and interesting, lots of EC opportunities in class but has clickers (20%) also in class, 4 exams each 20%
You are required to go to discussion like 25% of your grade depends on this...
Taken with Barton. Easiest of the series, most people will do better than they did in A and B. No curve, but tests are very fair.

Took with Rachel Wu. Really easy class. Quizzes can be taken twice, no midterm, final is online and open note. Assigned homework is minimal, just 3 simple newspaper article assignments throughout the quarter. Discussion section attendance part of grade. Go to lecture, read the textbook.

Had it with Professor Davis Spring 2020 and she is so nice. My TA was also amazing - Pamela Sheffler. Only thing you need to do to ace the class is memorize the slides. 4 exams, the lowest one gets dropped so if you're satisfied with your grade you don't need to take the "final".

I had Danielle Delany in summer session A for psych. She was super nice and easy-going. Her lectures were easy to understand. The tests were pretty much about the material covered in lecture. If you have her just make sure you know the lecture slides and you'll pass.

Took it with Prof SETO during online format and it was horrible to say the least. His exams required deep understanding of the material which he did not equip us for. I aced phys2A/B but I struggled with his teaching method in 2C. A lot of people would agree he could do MORE examples similar to what he would expect from us and just overall put more effort. I ended up with a B+ so its "do-able"

HELLA easy if you take this class with Professor Sy. Took this class during Fall 2020(online b/c of covid) and he only had 2 lectures live and made the rest of them asynchronous. Just keep up with watching the lectures(like 2 per week) and use the notes you take from them to fill out the study guides he sends out before the exams and you are guaranteed an A on the exams. Exams including the final were non-cumulative and open note + open textbook. Also, go to discussion because they take attendance and it counts towards your grade quite a bit.

I had Prof. Wu for PSYC002 during online classes. All of the lectures, quizzes, and exams are asynchronous, so it's super helpful to go at your own pace. My advice to make sure you don't procrastinate because it WILL screw you over in the end. Make sure you watch the lecture videos and attend the discussion and you'll be fine. I finished with an A.
Take with professor psy because he makes course easy

Took it with Coulombe. She talks really fast, but she makes the content pretty easy. If you took AP Stat, you're chill, but if you're not good with stat, you might need more practice. It's pretty straightforward except for the last two weeks (It's a little confusing, but still okay). Somewhat of an easy A if you pay attention tbh

Take with Dr. Annie Ditta if at all possible! She is overall extremely nice and understanding, and allows a cheatsheet (front and back of one paper) for exams. She also breaks down the concepts super simply and goes fairly slow/thorough to make sure everyone understands. Just understand the basic concepts/write down the differences between the types of tests for exams and you'll be fine.
Take with Prof. Natsuaki- makes sure you understand material and TA's pretty good

Took it with Duyen Trang. If you took AP stats in high school, then you'll be fine. If you didn't, Duyen does a great job at showing how to do it in a neat and easy way to understand. 2 midterms and 1 cumulative final - all open notes - that are open for several days for you to complete. About 3-4 homeworks are due before each midterm/final that are graded based on completion. Duyen also holds review section a day before each exam. Attend those because she goes over the study guide and it really helps.

Very math intensive. However, Natsuaki made this class pretty okay. I've never taken stats and I did fairly okay. Conceptually, it gets a little iffy at time and oh boy, the calculations are endless but not overall a super hard class. Lectures a bit boring but would recommend with Natsuaki overall.

Took it with Natsuaki in Fall (Online). Honestly stats was really scary going into this but I came out loving the subject. The course is vigorous so carry your weight and you’ll do well. Also don’t be afraid to go to office hours for your TA since they do all your grading. We had 3 midterms and  a cumulative final. Also one paper and 2 weekly assignments. Like I said it’s vigorous but it’s not innately hard. Discussions were not mandatory except the last one to show a portfolio (another assignment). I would definitely invest in an iPad or a tablet so you can hand write upload your homework and test work easily. It saves a lot of time during exams. Exams were not proctored but make sure you show your work.
Take over the summer so you don't have to complete 2+ research papers.

Took it with Prof Franchak. The textbook comes with inquizitive so make sure to do those assignments for easy points. 3 midterms and 1 cumulative final. Study his slides and take the practice quizzes and you should do fine. Grade is split 50/50 between lecture and lab (aka research papers) papers are most important ask your TAs for help and don’t procrastinate those

I had Prof. Ditta and she was honestly one of my favorite professors I’ve had. She allows a 1-paged (front&back) cheat sheet on all exams and allows test corrections to get points back on midterms. She is genuinely super helpful and wants her students to succeed.

Dr. Calanchini is a great professor and a very understanding person. He's great at applying concepts to relatable/funny real-life examples. Overall the material itself is easy, there's just kind of a lot of it. He does a "midterm" every 2 weeks (5 total, 20 questions each) which sounds awful but it makes the class way easier because you only have to memorize 2 weeks worth of material at a time rather than 5. They're usually pretty easy, and at least for Spring 2020 (online/during the pandemic), they were all open book/open notes. Usually there are 2 research proposals throughout the quarter but for Spring 2020 there was only 1. Either way, don't get behind on it! Also, DO THE INQUIZITIVES. They are basically practice for his "midterms"/final.

Took this online during Spring 2020. Dr. Calanchini is an awesome instructor and also very nice/pretty lenient. The material itself isn't hard but there is a LOT of work, mainly because of the research proposal project.

Dr. Franchak was good professor. I enjoyed his lectures that would often have a bit of humor embedded within. There was a lot of content that was covered, but Dr. Franchak did a great job of organizing how the content was taught. I appreciated his willingness to be lenient on assignment due dates. He explained everything well and gave plenty of opportunities for students to improve their grades. Everything was on quizlet pretty much (Online Spring Quarter 2020 btw).

This class was actually pretty nice. For a 6 unit class during Spring of 2020, it was manageable. The Prof (Franchak) was SUPER understanding of the events that were happening at the time. Just off of how lenient he was and understanding of how people were dealing with things (1 paper instead of the usual 2, dropped lowest test, very communicative) during those times, I would recommend.

Took with prof Franchak, he posts the lecture on Yuja. He is a great professor, there are 5 quizzes, final is a quiz as well. The quizzes are open note but you still need to know the material to answer the short answer questions. There is one 6 page research paper, but the discussion assignments help with it.

Psychology of Creativity: Professor Ditta is probably one of the best professors ever. She really prioritizes the learning and understanding of her students in terms of making her lectures very engaging by adding activities that help you understand the concepts. She has weekly quizzes that give you a sense of how she writes her exam questions which I find very useful. There are 2 midterms and 1 Final project (no final exam).

Annie Ditta was the professor and she was a new professor to UCR. She makes the class so engaging and brings in interesting guest lecturers. Exams are extremely easy if you just simply memorize the content/ use common sense. There's a project at the end of the class, it's very simple practically everyone gets 100s. Just make sure to show up to every discussion.

My professor was Dr. Abdulrazak. The class has a lot of information to remember, which made it difficult. Just read the lecture slides and textbook. There are 3 tests in total (“final” is not cumulative). Tests are fair, nothing too tricky. Average is usually ~76%. Also, there are 3 pop quizzes given in lecture so be sure to always attend class.

Dr. Peter Hickmott is amazing and uploads all the slides. Tests are totally based on lecture slides and it isn't that big of a deal if you miss some classes (attendance isn't taken), but he explains concepts really well and it's easier to study if you attend lecture. It's kind of a lot of work because there is a lot of material to study, but most of the concepts themselves aren't very hard and the class is enjoyable overall.

I had Dr. Hickmott. Two midterms, one final, no homework. This is a very difficult class, but his passion for the material and teaching puts the course in a propitious perspective. Best advice is ALWAYS stay on top of the material, especially if you're a neuroscience major!!! The exams cover lecture/discussion material, so attend both. He doesn't try to trick you - everything is straight forward - but do pay attention to the greater details.
Korzus’s exams were super hard for no reason. The exams were nothing like the study guide.
Quiz and essay/project heavy. Final is much harder than midterm.

description: CELLULAR NEUROSCIENCE: MEMBRANE AND SYNAPTIC PHENOMENA

comments.comment: Dr. Julia Revord is one of the nicest professors I've ever taken. She is super accommodating and taught the class really well. Lectures were asynchronous for the quarter I took it but honestly most of us only watched like 1 or 2 lectures and did fine, especially because it was all open-note/open book. No homework. Just some short multiple choice tests (20 questions) every so often, and the lowest one is dropped for your final grade. The topic is kind of interesting too. Highly recommend

Took this with Prof Hughes. Definitely take it with him if you can. He made the concepts easy to understand. Take notes and you’ll do well on the exams. Three 20 question midterms and a final and a short reflection paper. Best class
Prof. Sy is entertaining; he really makes an effort to be funny. Tests are easy and straightforward. The extra credit is crazy hard though.
Psy’s a fun prof, I didn’t go to lecture much (3 hrs at night? no thanks) but attendance is required for discussion and the TAs give pop quizzes in discussion on the chapter for the week. easy A.
Memorize the diagnostic criteria as soon as possible to make exams easier to handle. The final covers all 60+ disorders and there will be multiple case studies on it so don't forget them.
Dr. Rosenbaum made the class easy but the material itself was complicated. Interesting class but you need to go to lecture if you want an A.

I had professor Bruce Babcock. He's pretty cool, slightly unorganized. But if you go to lecture and do the 3 assignments, you'll be just fine. If you're interested in government you should have no problem taking interest into this class and getting a good grade. Readings not necessary

Took with Prof Babcock. Attend lectures and you'll be fine. Exams are fair and easy. Weekly readings but he goes over it during lectures so you don't really have to do them. 2 midterms and a cumulative final.

Honestly read the book before you attend lecture and really try to listen to professor Ramakrishnan. Doing all that reading and cramming the night before your Policy Brief, final, and midterm really isn't it, so get on top of it. Also T.A.'s will give you a long list of things to study, but like only a quarter of those things will be on the test. I barely attended lecture and I studied the night before my finals. Passed the class with a B+.
Taken with Babcock. Easy class somewhat tedious assingmnets.

prof brady fall 2020: exams & first two writing assignments were dumb easy, third 2000 word assignment should be ok if you don't procrastinate. dr. brady's really nice and although he's not v flexible for individuals he did make the final optional and promise a curve

Taken online with Professor Serieux-Lubin. Professor was extremely uninvolved, most interaction was through the TA. Never started anything before the day it was due in this class & got an A easily. 

-3 Written assignments (~200, 800, 2000 words)
-Exam every 2 week on 2 weeks of material that you learn from videos + linked readings. Used to be 2 short answer + multiple choice, was just multiple choice by the end of the quarter
-attendance taken once a week from discussion with the TA
-plenty of extra credit offered via discussion boards/submitting early drafts of written assignments

Took with Prof Brint. Group/partner discussions every lecture. Pop quizzes every week. 1 midterm and final. Interesting class and enjoyable. Quizzes & TA can make or break your grade. Optional debates that you can do but it is limited and assigned during the first lecture.

Taken with Professor Brint. Excellent teaching methods. Sometimes a bit slow on getting to the point. Class not difficult. Optional debates that can be substited for Midterm/Policy Report. Decently easy.
Relatively easy class, usually taught by Dr. Brint. Just study the slides and it is an easy A.
Took it with Prof Vergara-Tapia, class content was interesting and straightforward. There is a midterm and a final, and weekly quizzes. Most test questions come from lecture
Easy class - completetly asynrchronous. Taken with Serieux-Lubin. Super easy midterm and papers. Easy/Free A basically
Took it with Prof Serieux Lubin, she was really understanding and kind. The class is 2 papers, 4 discussion posts, a midterm and final. The test questions are straight from lecture too. Great class.
Class wasn't too hard, took it with Prof Seriuex Lubin during Fall 2020 so it was online and asynchronous. Open note midterm and final. She gives a lot of opportunity for extra credit near the end.
Very easy! 2 policy briefs that were short (minimum 500 words) and the TA was lenient.
serieux-lubin winter 2021: so, so many extra credit opportunities. really don't have to read anything, although the readings are pretty interesting in their own right

Took it with Sagan. Definitely take Ali as your TA. One midterm, one final, one paper, and three quizzes in section. As long as you follow the slides, the exams are pretty easy. The TA was very helpful and made sure we were well prepared. Do not need much prior knowledge on Jesus or religion.

I took this class with Professor Chang and I had Kori as a TA. They were both very nice and easy going. This class requires two books, one of them you can just find the pdf but I had to buy the other book. It was pretty much easy, just do your section's reading (the online class is set up in a specific way where you're broken up into groups and are given questions that correlate with your group number to which you answer during lectures). There was one midterm and one final, both of which Prof. Chang gave out study guides to (the guides were literally the exact same questions so make sure to do it, he also lets you use the guides during the exams). It's a pretty easy class, you don't really need to spend much energy and time on it.

Professor Bayer is an awesome and chill professor. He knows that most of his students are only taking the class as a requirement and doesn't try to force the material on students. Course consists of three end-of-section exams and one final project.

Took DEATH with Dr. Young Oh. No midterms, pop quizzes every week, & open notes final exam. Writing assignments every other week plus the additional writing assignments near week 8-9, one of them is about visiting a death site. A lot of reading so pop quizzes can make or break your grade. Discussion section is weighted similar to the final exam so make sure to attend. A lot of work but extremely interesting class.

Dr Ana Bajzelj is definitely one of the best professors I've had at UCR. I took this class online in spring 2020 and she was extremely accommodating for all students during that time, as well as very accessible outside of class through email and office hours. There was a fair bit of reading (academic papers, mostly) but it was very interesting and related to the lectures, which were also very interesting. I took this class for an elective but I enjoyed engaging with the material, even if it was a bit overwhelming at times. However, the lectures are very comprehensive and sometimes a skim of the reading is all you need.

Took the class with Professor Cristina Rosetti and I loved it! It's called "Death" and it was a very interesting class. She made it an interesting class. Was very well organized, no midterm/final but there is a paper proposal and a 5 page paper and a quiz each week. The quiz is just written responses to questions she asks in lecture (2) and she lets you know when the quizzes are. It's more so opinion based and to see if you understood the topic. The "final" paper is fairly easy, just make sure you write on time and not the day before.
Only take with professor simmons

Honestly if you put some effort in you should get an A pretty easily. Had San Juanita Garcia, tests were straightforward, but she's a bit unorganized. Just review slides or read the textbook and you'll be fine.

Really easy class. Garcia just kinda reads off her slides and goes really fast so be prepared for that. The textbook will be needed but only minimally; tests are based mostly on lecture notes and you'll get a study guide before each

Simmers is an awesome professor. Tells great stories. Threw a haymaker on the second midterm, but there are a couple of extra credit opportunities for discussion and doing the bonus synthesis (only if you did the first 5 synthesis activities). Final was noncumulative

Took it with Professor Simmons. Don't underestimate Sociology. READ the textbook, as it is where most of the information for the course comes from. Easy C if you just review the google docs before the midterms, but if you want a B or an A, you need to read and actually know the concepts as her test were not definition based but were more conceptual in terms of applying your knowledge to real life examples and context.  I got a B, and I read every chapter and attended all the lectures. She is funny AF, so thats always a positive of attending lecture. Does not post lecture slides, but can get them if you make friends. Otherwise a good and insightful class to take, but reading is required for a good grade.

Jennifer Summers is great. Extra credit just from doing all 6 synthesis activities and going to discussion. Got an A on the first midterm and was able to slack off on the second midterm and final and still got an A.

Took with San Garcia. Extremely nice and inspiring. Class is really easy and you don't need to buy the textbook since she uploads the lecture slides with the information you need for the exams. Make sure to do the packback on time since it's worth like 10% of your grade. Your TA can make or break your grade.

The lecturer is amazing. I could listen to her read off a phone book, but the course requires 3 midterms based off of 100 pages of reading each. It's just more work than I wanted to put in for what was supposed to be my "easy" class.

Schmitt’s both lecture & reading heavy for his course! Exams are lengthy & heavily worded so it’s quite neck breaking if you need to understand a question clearly. For an introductory class, it’s much more challenging & in depth than most. Study double the time & make your own charts to balance his lectures & readings!

Don't take Christopher Schmitt!! He gave a 2 day midterm, one was written answers and then multiple choice. The final was 100 questions multiple choice, although he told us we might have a written just to mess with our minds a little more. :) His lectures are unorganized and not helpful at all (he writes a few words on the slides and talks about random life experiences he had which he tries to relate to the class) and he makes us read random chapters in the textbook instead of just in order. Typos and confusing questions were a regular occurrence in his midterm and final. Hard final and it was 45% of grade while midterm was 40%. Anyone saying it was easy or a good class is a liar. Coming from someone who got almost 100% on that hard midterm.
The exams were difficult. They were mostly lecture based but the format of the the questions were overall hard. The readings were not all that hard and the professor gave a lot of exam hints.
the way professor schmitt taught was odd. there were no notes to write down. you had to catch everything he said as you never know what would really be on the quizzes and exams

professor schmitt makes this class unnecessarily hard, but if you do take him get ready to study everything: lecture notes, textbook, and videos he shows in class. the final was really hard compared to the midterm.

I had Rotondi, it was extremely difficult for an intro class. the class itself isn't bad, it's just him. he's a great lecturer and funny guy. there are 2 midterms, a final and a paper (which is basically the easiest assignment we got). however, his tests are extremely tedious. he over complicates the questions, and it's mainly based on readings (which are extremely heavy). class is interesting, exams and readings are unnecessarily hard for an INTRO class.
If u get prof. Rotondi, then drop it. He made the class way too hard. It is an intro class but didn't feel like an intro with him. He made the class way too hard.

Took it online with Prof Janet Hill, class material in itself wasn't too hard. Midterm and final questions come from lectures, readings, and videos/films. Don't know if it was because it was online, but it felt like the class required a lot of work for a lower div.

Not a difficult class but avoid Dr Hill if you get the chance. Was very vague about the midterm and yelled at me in front of a Zoom lecture of ~250 people when I tried to ask about it. Hard to reach by email and quite stubborn. Very unprofessional.
quizzes every week, rotondi pushed back paper and quizzes (pretty understanding), heavy reading and lots of recorded lectures
Had Rotondi was extremely hard, 120 pages of reading a week, a quiz every week two different books plus about 2-3 hours of lecture videos a week sheesh.

I had Rotondi for Fall 2020 and he made it really difficult for an intro class. The weekly quizzes are insanely specific and are based on 100+ pages. Irrelevant details you don't think are going to be on the quiz, WILL BE ON THE QUIZ. I spent hours studying the readings and worked really hard to get an A, so DO NOT take this class if you have other classes to prioritize. He gave an extra credit quiz but that might have just been because of the circumstances of this quarter. The paper was easy because the TAs are pretty lenient. You can not slack in this class, I know many people that failed this course because of his quizzes so be aware.

I had Rotondi for this class (Fall 2020). He’s a great professor. He’s very passionate about his teaching. READ! READ! READ! The class has quizzes and doesn’t have final.You’ll pass the quizzes as long as you read.

Very challenging course because there is a lotnof memeorization of theories and terms. However, it was insightful and interesting! I do only recommend this class to Soc majors or people interested in it. I know many people who failed the class...

Tests were all multiple choice based off lecture notes, not reading. Assignments are repetitive and more or less busy work and the last paper was basically a repeat of the first five assignments compiled together. I took it with Prof. Hill and she’s not the best lecturer. Be prepared to listen to her drone on and on about her personal life during class.

Took it with Prof. Perry ( Amy Perry ). She made it an easy class if you attended the lectures, because thats what the 4 quizzes were based off of. If you attend the lectures, you don't have to read because she just talks about it instead. The lowest quiz is dropped.

Took this class with Schmitt, was pretty easy to follow cus it was online. Asynchronous lectures, 1 quiz, non cumulative midterm and final, both multiple choice, & 2 short response papers. The test questions were tricky and hard sometimes, but if u do the readings then it'll be a lot easier
If the professor is Amy Kroska, DO NOT TAKE THE CLASS. She's a terrible professor.
I took this class with Kalousova and it was pretty hard. Go to discussions and put in work, doing homework cost like $120. Not an impossible class but definitely not an easy A

Took this class with Matthew Rotondi, do not take if you're not ready to read. Easily 40 pages per class and the tests are very specific on material. An interesting professor but not worth the workload.

Taken with Matthew Rotondi. I assumed this would be an easy A breadth course but he made the class so much more difficult than it needed to be. Very heavy on readings (you can command+F most of the articles since the exams are open note) and strict grading on the short answer portion of the tests. The plus side was that there were no discussions or homework assignments, just 3 exams total, and lectures were completely asynchronous.

Took this class with Rotondi and there is a LOT of coursework. Tons and tons of articles to read and the quizzes and exam questions are pretty specific to the articles. Some articles are extremely dense as well.

I took this class with Professor Rotondi and it was super difficult. I'm not sure who his TA was or how they graded papers. It seemed like he thought he was helping by changing deadlines. Remote learning was hard.

Horrible class; no TAs, Professor Chase-Dunn makes you read his own textbook + 4 other full textbooks, he grades all the assignments himself and the grades distributed are usually based on what he considers is correct; no rubric. Students were all extremely overworked and the curve still failed many of us. I spend 2 all-nighters in order to finish 40 assigned pages for this class and still failed. Ruined my love for sociology.
Jennifer Simmon is a good professor, straightforward about what she expects. The material isn’t too heavy, I didn’t study as hard so I got a B. Decent quizzes & exams aren’t crazy.
Some TAs graded the essays much harder than the others.

Such a caring professor, clear criteria, optional zoom class because he records them all. A lot of readings & exams aren’t crazy unless you don’t read everything he mentions as well as watch lecture. Overall would take again but study!

description: THE SOCIOLOGY OF WORK IN ORGANIZATIONS

comments.comment: I had Senora Ballester and she’s a very nice professor. She’s very helpful but she teaches at a very fast pace and gives a lot of work. Classes are also mandatory and she makes you show your face on zoom.

Professor Ballester is an AMAZING teacher! At first it seems like she is going really fast but her teaching style is great. I knew NO spanish and can actually understand it very well. Shes always open to giving feedback on homework and compositions so never hesitate to ask if you want that perfect score on your homework. Honestly  wish I could take her for spanish 2 because she ultimately wanted us to have a good understanding of spanish. Lots of class and homework though but pretty easy!
Kind of tedious and annoying. Especially if you have Yolanda Cardenas. Good Professor, but it will require a lot of work from you with an exam one week and a composition the next.

Winter 2021: Antonio Montoya. I’m a non native speaker with 4years of high school spanish (including AP Spanish). Overall the grading is harsh but he does try to make it easy for us to understand. He’s very helpful when it comes to addressing questions or homework. You have to actively participate during Zoom and turn on your camera. He takes attendance. The class consists of using McGraw broken down into 8 sections and everyday (Mon-Thur) the assignment deadline is due the next day before class starts instead of 11:59pm. There’s also chapter quizzes based on the homework and textbook. Two writing compositions during class time. Midterm is an individual oral presentation. I feel like this class was way easier than high school but I tend to forget everything so it was basically a review course but also relearning what I forgot. He wasn’t mean or rude like I hear about the other Spanish professors. The class was chill. Take him if you can! If you know more on speaking Spanish then this class would be easy for you.

Taken during winter 2021. a lot of work and tedious especially if you aren't the best at Spanish. Lots of homework (every night plus studying). Grades somewhat hard for it only being Spanish 2. Attendance is also mandatory plus having your camera on

I took this class with Pedro Garcia Lopez and while he was nice, he was a tough grader and really expects you to get down Spanish. Class has 2 written exams, 5 textbook assignments and quizzes, 2 oral presentations (one for the midterm and one for the final), and a final written exam. However, the textbook assignments/quizzes are 30% of your grade, so do good on those and try to get B's on the other assignments. Be prepared because the quizzes can take a while to complete because of how lengthy the questions are. Plus the textbook was online and terrible (not to mention it was 50 bucks).

If you are a Spanish speaker this is the easiest class basically GPA booster. If you are not a Spanish speaker this class will take a huge amount of time, make sure you practice a lot. If possible try to pair up or be friends with a Spanish speaker. Homework heavy!! professor navarro is honestly so sweet and he really does care, also super funny.

Taken Winter 2021 (COVID-19 Remote Learning). Class is taught entirely by TA/Student Instructor. Heavy reliance on online textbook for homework, quizzes, and final. The online textbook is very specific about what kinds of answers it accepts, so be prepared to go into Office Hours often to fight to get points back. Pretty much daily homework assignments (30 minutes max), 2 short essays, 4 quizzes, two oral assessments (1 presentation, and 1 conversation), and then an online final in the same format as the quizzes/homework. Sounds like a lot, but it is spaced out nicely over the 10 weeks. For my class, cameras were required to be on, which made the class really enjoyable! Nice to interact with people.
Hard grader. Professor Vargas very strict with native speakers, but prepares you well especially if desiring a major/minor in Spanish.

Class is hella easy compared to 109A. Taken with Mirta Copa Vargas and even though the class was hella on her head for being hard, she was not. Her essay topics can be confusing but asking others in the class is key to understanding what to write about. Once you understand her essay prompt/expectations her class is cake. I did essays two days before and walked out with an A.

description: INTRODUCTION TO LITERARY CRITICISM AND ANALYSIS

comments.comment: Jill Smith is the easiest professor
Jill Smith is a great professor--the class is easy and the averages are usually in the upper 70's.  That being said, don't fall behind on class notes.  There's a few tricky topics.
Professor Analisa is great.

Jill Smith was lecturer, she can be pretty boring but she isn't horrible. The material itself isn't that horrible either but I think it got pretty weird in the end. She posts half written notes online and doesn't post annotated versions so make sure you go to lecture and copy whatever she writes down.
Taken with Flores. Material is relatively easy, but be warned there is a discussion and lab, so be warned that it will require some work.

Took it with Joyce Fu while classes were online. She's extremely sweet and lenient, but not the best professor. I would recommend going to office hours regularly. Overall class was relatively easy, but the first few weeks' worth of material was definitely confusing because of her teaching style. Don't fall behind on the lectures because things start to pick up around weeks 3-4. The midterm, quizzes, and final were pretty ok. She let us have a cheat sheet for both the midterm and final, too.
Super easy. Easier than Dirty 30 and I never even took Stat100A. Professor Cappiello and the TA's are absolute studs. Textbook is also free as a PDF or $20 (new) on amazon.

Dr. Yingzhou Fu (aka Joyce) is to be avoided if at all possible. I only understood her lectures because I learned the topics right before I took the course, otherwise I would've been completely lost like everyone else. The OpenIntro textbook isn't super helpful, I'd recommend looking up YouTube videos to teach yourself.

I took this class with during Yingzhou Fu's first quarter teaching, which make it unsurprising that I was quite lost for the whole quarter. Most people agreed that if not for the TA's in lab and discussion it would've been hard to actually learn. Since it was her first quarter, she made the class pretty easy to pass.

I had Dr. Fu. She was organized but would go off tangent at times so it was hard to follow through with lectures. But the TA's were super helpful and clarified many topics. Midterms weren't too bad, so long as you did the homework. A lot of the questions were from the homework, just different values. Labs were pretty straightforward as well. Just put in a little work and you'll get that A!
Take with Joyce Fu, she allows a sheet of notes on the midterm and final. No curve, but the average score was a B+. It is a lot of information to take in, so be prepared to practice a lot

the ta’s were really good however the course required a certain amount of self studying in order to truly grasp the material. Easy class to get an A but it was only so-so in preparation for other courses
Taught by Linda Penas - Boring professor, she reads off of her presentations. The tests are easy, because they're mostly open book.
Very organized and straightforward.
Strict grading but very straightforward class. Focus on labs and practice exams.
The the practice exam is very similar to the actual midterm exam

Took this over the summer with Luke Klein. He taught this course pretty well and was also a great TA for another class. 2 tips: 1) This is a (guided) coding class more than a straight up stats class. Be prepared to rewrite/retry lines of code. 2) ALWAYS WATCH THE VIDEOS/READ THE TEXTBOOK/use the other main materials. It basically gives you the answers verbatim anyway so it's worth!

I had Professor Analisa Flores and she is the sweetest. She clearly cares about her students mental state and is always willing to hear any concerns or questions in regards to the course. Thought the quarter, she was extremely helpful with homework and lab assignments, while quickly responding to emails. There is 1 midterm, 1 final where you must “study everything” but overall is not too bad. Homework, lab, notes, and practice exercises can be tedious, but is doable. Just don’t wait till the last minute to complete the work !

I had Professor Analisa Flores and she is the sweetest. She clearly cares about her students mental state and is always willing to hear any concerns or questions in regards to the course. Thought the quarter, she was extremely helpful with homework and lab assignments, while quickly responding to emails. There is 1 midterm, 1 final where you must “study everything” but overall is not too bad. Homework, lab, notes, and practice exercises can be tedious, but is doable. Just don’t wait till the last minute to complete the work !

description: PROBABILITY AND STATISTICS FOR SCIENCE AND ENGINEERING

comments.comment: I had Zhiwei Zhang. Zhang allows us to bring one paper of our own notes to exams. He doesn't curve, but if you have good notes and understand the homework, you shouldn't be struggling that much. The actual content is very easy for the most part. I only seriously looked at the lecture notes the day before exams to make my notes and ended up doing well.

Zhiwei Zhang. Lectures are pretty boring. The professor is pretty monotonous, not everybody can pay attention in those environment. Two midterms, one final. No quizzes in discussion, at least for spring 18. Homework is done on webassign, you can just google the problems if you don't understand. Just another statistics class needed to graduate. I don't understand but just do it it's required. You don't learn too much anyhow.

Not that bad. Took it with Zhang. First midterm was super easy. Second midterm was quite difficult. The final was slightly easier than the second midterm. Homeworks were annoying but doable. 

My advice is get serious after the first midterm.

Professor Zhiwei Zhang. Hard to understand during lectures but is a really nice guy that will always be eager and thorough when answering your e-mails or when you attend his office hours. This class is extremely easy(like Algebra 2 easy) during the first third of it up to and including the first midterm. The content up to the second midterm and final will be noticeably harder(I'd say probably 3-4x as difficult). The key to doing well in this class is doing well on the homework and spending a lot of time on your formula sheet to ensure you have no blind spots in your understanding. The average on the first midterm was 16/20 and the second was 10/20 so you can kind of see what I mean.
I had Jill Smith. It's not as hard as it seems, it just requires a lot of time and energy outside of class that I did not really have.

Had Prof. Smith, class ramps up in difficultly pretty quickly after the first midterm. Probably not the most challenging math course you will ever have but definitely not a walk in the park. Homework is through WebAssign, and is much harder than the exams in my opinion. If you can do the homework well without too much assistance you will do well in the class. Go to office hours and put in a decent amount of time studying for the class and you'll be fine. It also helps if your TA was as helpful as mine, Tyler.
Didn't go to class after the midterm, but still got an A in the class. You'll be alright.

CS Major's Opinion: Took this class with Jill and let me tell your this class will eat you alive if you're not into Math. 

First lets talk about the HW. It's Web Assign with three overall submission tries meaning each try counts for the entire assignment. The HW's are insanely long to do and all pretty much word problems so if you hated those well here they are to fuck you one last time before you graduate. The biggest helpful advice I can give you is to recognize what type of question each problem is asking you and to do each HW before the Quizzes.

The Quizzes themselves are the HW so if you do them before they are due you'll have a fighting chance. A lot of people didn't pick this up until too late. Every discussion ends with a quizz and yeah you get a quizz and HW literally a day before the final. Jill has no mercy.

All in all if you can get 90% and above on the HW's and Quizzes you may just pass this class but it won't be an easy task. THE HW IS HARD. This is a heavy class to balance and if you don't put time and effort into this class you'll definitely repeat it.

The exams and homework were not hard. But the way the class is structured with Shuheng Zhou are what make it frustrating to take. There are no recordings for lectures. No chat during lectures. Which makes it hard to deal with especially for a 3 hour block once a week class.

Probability and Combinatorics are the hardest part of this class. Sometimes differentiating between probability distributions can be tricky but if you keep up, this class will be easy. Make sure to do the HW as this is the most helpful part in ensuring a good grade on tests. Lectures are confusing so reading the book instead is useful. Teacher: Shuheng Zhou

Taught by Linda Penas - significantl harder, because you're only learning SAS. And SAS is a horrible program. The materials are actually a little bit harder so pay attention in class, if you can stay awake.

I recommend Professor Bucklin for this class. He is funny, grades easily as long as you put in some effort for your acting, and practically gives you an "A" if you show up to the lecture (participation counts). There is no h.w. for this class. He occasionally gives small quizzes on the plays/screen writes (which can be found online) and write a short review for a play. The final is also super easy (it's a 3-5 min group performance, you get full points for participation).
This class with Buklin was pretty easy. Only 1 midterm, 2 quizzes about easy plays, and no final. He's easy to understand.

description: PRODUCTION TECHNIQUEST FOR THEATRE, FILM, AND TELEVISION

comments.comment: Annika Speer has fantastic lectures that are entertaining and engaging, absolutely do the readings, they’re not bad and genuinely helped for the midterm. Write your speeches about topics you care about!!

1. Start the reading early and the class should be straight forward. Professor Speer is extremely helpful and engaging in class. Participating in class is useful for feedback that helps with your skills in class. The class is graded mostly by the TA through the speeches, so follow the feedback given.

Michael Bucklin. Easy screenwriting class, I think he said something like 70% of the class get A's so. Mostly effort based rather than actual content based. Lecture, discussion and screening. Screening is one movie per week. Some basic projects but not too much of a time commitment to them to be honest. I just make sure to show up (attendence) and turn in assignments and it'll be pretty difficult to not pass the class. Midterm from the textbook, short answer form. No final, just final project 5-7ish page outline of script.
